output: Madam Vice President, the Commission gives the impression of acting like a distracted student rushing to make up for lost time before handing in their exam paper.
Certainly, the social package exists, but it is incomplete and can only be considered as a step towards the Commission taking social issues into account.

The President of the Commission failed to grasp the warning issued by citizens in France, the Netherlands, and Ireland, which would unfortunately have been identical elsewhere in the event of a popular vote.
These elections are wake-up calls.
If Europeans want more Europe, it is to build a social project and not simply to adopt even more technical directives.
Regulations pertaining to the internal market are certainly necessary, but they are not, and by far not, the essential element.
The 2009 program, like its predecessors, will miss the point.
Citizens do not expect the Commission to merely supplement, nor even to simplify legislation.
They await the Commission's ability to rise to the task assigned to it by the treaties, the driving force, the think tank of the Union.
It is not enough for that its president be wise and silent, standing at attention behind the President of the Council.
We expect the Commission to act as a key player in the reflection on the nature of the society we need.
But what is the vision of society underpinning this program?
The 2009 program does not contain serious errors, but it is not the program our fellow citizens need.
Mr. President, it will be up to the new College to assume its responsibilities.
I only hope that he will be less deaf to the calls of the people than the current one.
Mr. President, first a question to the Council.

What about the high-level conference on Georgia that had been proposed by the French presidency, and how does the current presidency of the Union intend to defend Georgia’s territorial integrity, given that one country recognizes two separatist regions, Abkhazia and South Ossetia?
But it's a shame that Mr. Barroso isn't here, because in his speech, he wasn't convincing—perhaps because he himself isn't convinced by the proposals he has put forward to us.
I believe that the financial and economic situation is far more serious than he described.
Even today, I believe those who follow the internet see very well that stock markets continue to collapse despite interventions.

For me, it represents the collapse of the current system, a system entirely obsolete, the system that led to bankruptcy, that led a land to be totally exploited and suffocated by greenhouse gas emissions, that resulted in underdevelopment in the South and that resulted in underdevelopment in our cities.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, the current financial crisis clearly demonstrates that when the problem is global, a global response is required.
And this is particularly true in the field of agriculture or in the food sector.
This is precisely why, for example, the World Trade Organization was created—an organization with which we agree—which seeks to establish globalized rules.

It so happens that it doesn't work quite as we would like, because we are facing a problem which is as follows: we must reconcile two things – free trade, which is necessary and on which everyone agrees, but protections, which are equally necessary.
and the protections of national economies or agricultures do not equate to protectionism.
To achieve this, the path we have taken for sixty years, since the GATT, has been an unbalanced one, moving towards the reduction of tariffs, with the objective of their elimination.
It so happens that, technically, the reduction of customs duties
It's difficult. The proof, a whole series of mathematical formulas, the South Korean formula, the European formula, or the best-known formula, the Swiss formula.
It doesn’t really work because a product is not unitary.
It is composed of numerous elements with rules of very different origins, and reducing customs duties technically is not as simple as one might think.
We are therefore in a technical impasse, and politically, through negotiations, we are attempting to overcome it.
Alternatively, it so happens that, technologically, scientists have invented a new customs technology: the technology of export duty deductions from the importing State’s economy.
Concretely, this deductible customs duty transforms into a customs credit equal to the amount of the customs duty borne by the exporter in the importing country.
This customs credit has three characteristics: it is refundable, negotiable, and eligible for bonus.
It is refundable at the moment when the exporter, upon purchasing from the importer, can deduct the customs duty he has borne.

It is negotiable because if the exporting company that has borne 100% in customs duties has nothing to purchase from the importer, it negotiates without customs credit on the stock market or with a bank.
It is beneficial if, when we wish to assist developing countries, the importer offers a credit line exceeding the amount of import duties.
With this technique, we create an international currency of exchange whose monetary mass equals the amount of existing customs duties.
For example, the European Union would offer thirteen billion euros in international currency within the commercial sector.

Mr. President, the Russo-Georgian conflict and the financial crisis provided the European Union with the opportunity to assert itself on the world stage as a fully-fledged and leading political actor.
Thanks to your determination, Mr. President of the Council, Europe has managed to unite and find coordinated, effective, and rapid responses.
Faced with crises, Europe demonstrates that it exists and proves its added value.
Regarding immigration, for example, the every man for himself approach was no longer tenable.
The European Council’s adoption of the pact on immigration and asylum, initiated by the French presidency, represents a significant step forward.
Regarding the fight against climate change, Europe must set concrete objectives and lead by example for its global partners.

You have already expressed yourself on this matter, Mr. President of the Council, but we wish this agreement to be as balanced as possible, as it must take into account the economic situation of our countries, which are currently very destabilized.
but also raise the question of the type of development we will choose for the future.
To meet the challenges that await it, the European Union needs the Treaty of Lisbon more than ever.
We understand the concerns of our Irish friends, but the status quo is not an option.
Ireland must propose a solution at the December European Council; many of us are calling for it.
In recent weeks, we have observed with pride a strong, united Europe in adversity, resolute in its dealings with partners, and listened to on the international stage.
We desire that this new European mindset become the norm and endure.
The Treaty of Lisbon is the best solution available to us for achieving that.
Madam President, Minister, I was in Tbilisi when President Sarkozy came to negotiate the peace plan, and, of course, I pay tribute to him for having acted swiftly and knowing how to stop that war.
But this war is, in a sense, our failure. We have been hesitant for fourteen years; we have silently witnessed the escalation of provocations in the separatist regions.

This war, indeed, has roused Europe, placing it before its responsibilities. But the fires continue to engulf the Caucasus, and we must do everything in our power to definitively resolve the frozen conflicts for the security of all of Europe.
I am also aware, Mr. Minister, of the divisions among European countries regarding Georgia’s entry into NATO, and I am personally opposed.
I will make a proposal: I will ask the European Union to propose the status of neutrality for these Caucasian countries.
Only the status of neutrality can appease tensions with Russia and definitively prevent this subregion from further conflicts.
This status will ensure the security of these young democracies and contribute to our own security.
Commissioner, Minister, these past three days have seen the European Development Days, during which the food crisis affecting the poorest countries was extensively discussed.
All interventions emphasized the absolute necessity for developing countries to develop their own agriculture by optimally utilizing their land and natural resources.

Incidentally, the lyrical outbursts of those who called for, and still call for today, a reduction in state intervention, public spending, liberalization in all directions, privatization, and the relegation of agriculture as…
This near-prehistoric activity, this volte-face in favor of massive public investments in agricultural production and food sovereignty, all of it had something both ludicrous and scandalous about it.
The future of agriculture in developing countries has a direct relationship with the debate we are having today.

I regret to say that I do not feel this health check of the CAP, initiated before the peak of the famines and the disastrous market disruptions, takes into account the situation of Southern farmers and draws all the necessary conclusions from the severe crises we are experiencing today – ecological, social, economic, and financial.

I therefore deeply regret that the strong relationship between Northern and Southern agricultures is so little addressed, both in the Commission’s proposals and in the Parliament’s report. The reconsideration of the promised one billion euros demonstrates how much further there is to go.
Mr. President, the report we will vote on tomorrow marks the culmination of a year of work and negotiations dedicated to the future of the Common Agricultural Policy and our farmers.
Indeed, it was last November twentieth that Madame Fischer-Boel presented her proposals concerning the health assessment.
Following Lutz Goebbels’ progress report, here comes Capula Santos’ report on the Commission’s proposal.
We must commend our two colleagues for their excellent work.
The European Parliament's agriculture committee managed to remain firm against the initial proposals from the Commission, which we considered to be far too liberal.
I will remain vigilant regarding the dairy sector and, in particular, the measures preceding the abolition of quotas.

I am particularly thinking of mountain dairy producers, who must not be the poor relations of this reform, and it will be essential to ensure they are not left aside, as they will need greater support than others.
I do not wish to play Cassandra, but how can one imagine the French dairy industry consolidated within a single region?
Therefore, I welcome the proposal to establish a milk fund with goodwill, and that which proposes to evaluate, as early as 2010, the increase in dairy quotas in accordance with market developments.

The calculation of the gradual modulation performed by the Agriculture Commission appears to me to be fair and would allow us to strengthen the development of territories, rural areas, and sustainably preserve biodiversity.
I also commend the clarification of the ecoconditionality, the implementation of which had previously been a genuine challenge for farmers.

I also wish that we retain the tobacco fund amount, which allows us to maintain small farms in Europe, as well as a not insignificant workforce in a region where nothing else is exploitable, and which enables us to avoid imported products.
Finally, Minister, we greatly appreciated your commitment throughout these negotiations.
You have demonstrated considerable patience and determination, and you have not accounted for your time without sincerity.
It was a genuine pleasure to have worked alongside you.
You will have been of great effectiveness with us.
I know that we can rely on
Mr. President, thank you first for the work done and the conclusions and orientations proposed by the health check of the CAP report by Mr. Capoulos Santos.
Agriculture is indeed an economic sector that cannot respond to simple market signals.
Its activity has impacts, of course, on food self-sufficiency, but also—and this is too often overlooked—on territories and employment.
The removal of market instruments would be a severe blow to our agriculture.

Decoupling, for example, represents a genuine difficulty for certain livestock territories, particularly those raising beef cattle and sheep, and I am pleased to have heard Ms. Fischer Boll address this issue earlier.
Moreover, it is clear that the strict adherence to historical references would severely hinder any possibility of reform.
However, I still believe that the issue of the second pillar of the CAP is an essential one, because rural areas need to rely on agricultural activity to develop employment in rural communities.
And therefore, it is necessary to reflect on this problem of the second foot, without, of course, amputating the first.
Given that Minister Jouillet is leaving us, I believe this Parliament should thank him.
He was one of the most diligent ministers we have known.
I wish them good luck.

Madam President, I voted in favor of the PERI report concerning the integration of the OCM twenty into the single CMO, and I must say with a heavy heart, because I believe that this single CMO is not a simplification and does not increase transparency.
It will make life more complicated for winegrowers, for the entire wine-making sector.
Last night, the commissioner attempted to reassure us.

I hope that the Commission will keep its word and that, above all, the profession will continue to be adequately represented on the advisory committee, as has been the case since the first Common Organisation of Markets twenty.
Sir.
Mr. President, Minister, Commissioner, dear colleagues, our group enthusiastically supports the Small Business Act presented to us by the Commission last June.

Indeed, since the year 2000, initiatives have been undertaken targeting SMEs, and I am thinking particularly of the excellent work of our colleague Dominique Blasto on the charter for SMEs—initiatives that were appreciated but deemed insufficient because they too often remained mere aspirations.
Today, we must go further.
The severe economic crisis that our countries are experiencing and the consequences of which are particularly concerning for SMEs invite us to do so, if such an invitation were needed.
In this regard, the Small Business Act is part of a new, decidedly proactive approach.
In a few weeks, we will examine Madame Herzog's report on Commission communication, but today, through the submission of this oral question, we wished to engage the Council.

Dear Minister,

we have reviewed with interest the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Competitiveness Council and would like to know whether the European Council of 11 and 12 December next

will effectively relay its conclusions and provide a strong impetus to ensure that the overarching principle of “Think Small First” is rapidly transposed into the regulatory framework of the Member States.
We wish the Council to commit to the principle of the action plan annexed hereto, along with concrete measures.
In this regard, and within the limited time allotted to me, I will emphasize three directions in which we require binding impetus.
impact assessments that should be systematic and regular monitoring, with European Parliament oversight, of the implementation of the Small Business Act in Member States,
access to the public market
The code of good conduct has no binding force; we must, collectively, be more imaginative, more inventive, and propose concrete, tailored measures that genuinely open these markets to SMEs.
Finally, access to financing, more indispensable than ever in the current context.
Your proposals are sound, Minister, they must also incorporate support for supply.
There is an urgent need.
Thank you for confirming the Council’s willingness.

Mr. President, Minister, and Commissioner, we all know that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union, employing over seventy percent of the European Union’s workforce and accounting for ninety-nine percent of European businesses.

But as has already been stated, these millions of small and medium-sized enterprises are now concerned and threatened by the financial crisis because it degrades household purchasing power and confidence, and impacts order books.

It is therefore the cash flow of SMEs that is at risk, and it is consequently necessary to ensure their activities are supported by guaranteeing that banks provide effective access to the financing necessary for the continuation of their operations.
This is precisely the challenge of the conclusions from the Competitiveness Council of December 1st, discussed by the Minister, and of the recovery plan approved by the European Finance Ministers.
Making the needs of SMEs a permanent political priority of the Union is essential, and I wished to commend the action plan for the Small Business Act for Europe.
It does, indeed, reflect the desire to ensure the effective application of the guiding principle of prioritizing SMEs first, that is to say, European SMEs.
However, as the Commissioner has said, and as we all say, the Council must genuinely engage with the other institutions.
European. For this principle to be made effective now, it is necessary to move beyond the scope of the declaration and proceed to its implementation in all European policies and programs.
However, we can say that this action plan represents a genuine response to the urgency of the situation.
And I wished to acknowledge, Minister, the dynamism of the French presidency of the Union, which has enabled the swift translation of intentions into action.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, I fully support the rapporteur who is defending the position that was ours in the first reading, a position rejected by the governments of the Member States.
It was urgent to align our custody legislation with the jurisprudence of the Court of Justice, and that has been done.
The Cercas report provides balanced and protective responses for employees.
All on-call time is counted as working time.
Compensatory rest follows immediately after the period of service.
It is a matter of common sense to ensure decent working conditions, particularly for medical professions.
But the reform of the Working Time Directive also gives us the opportunity to advance our European social law by abolishing the individual opt-out.
The Cercas report seized this opportunity and proposes a gradual elimination of any possibility of derogating from the statutory maximum working time.
We must face reality.
It is a joke to say that the employee finds themselves in a position of equality with their employer and can refuse what is offered to them.
Dear colleagues, we must clearly demonstrate to the governments of the Member States that the text it wishes to impose on us is unacceptable.

Amidst the chorus of praise that will undoubtedly fill the ears of the French government starting tomorrow, it seems necessary to focus first and foremost on the employees who will be called upon to work increasingly long hours without genuine choice, much like all those who will be asked to work on Sundays in France tomorrow.
It is, moreover, evidently to open up this possibility that the French government has changed its position on individual opt-outs within the Council.

Dear colleagues, let us listen to the employees and try to respond to their call, so that we do not want the negative votes of the French, Dutch, and Irish referendums to be followed by many others, challenging a European Union that would leave them with the feeling of not addressing their everyday concerns. Thank you.
Mr. President, this was a truly excellent French presidency.
There were very few dissenting voices, to say the least.
The twenty-seven set aside their differences to reach a series of decisions that were exemplary.
On the energy-climate package, Europe takes a first step, and in that, this first step is immense.
She now has the means to assume her environmental responsibility without sacrificing her economy.
It can, from now on, take the lead in this area to guide other continents towards sustainable development.
Furthermore, Ireland is offering a scenario to escape its isolation.
Our Irish friends will pronounce themselves once again on the Treaty of Lisbon, with all the cards in hand, since virtually all other members will have definitively declared their position.
Current crises demonstrate that the Union needs, more than ever, the best institutional tools to be effective.
The European Council adopted a massive and coordinated economic recovery plan, based on long-term productive investment and targeted support for the industrial sectors most severely affected.
President Sarkozy raised the issue of reducing certain VAT rates, and I fully share his perspective.
Let us hope that the ministers of economy and finance will reach an agreement in March, an agreement that seemed impossible to the heads of state and government last weekend.
The trials faced by Europeans offer the Union an opportunity to demonstrate itself as more united, more responsive, and more concerned with their protection.
We are grateful to the French Presidency for having instilled this new dynamic.
We wish, as did Nicolas Sarkozy, not to see again any time soon the councils of yesterday that ended at four in the morning to negotiate three peanuts.
Over the past six months, Europe has genuinely changed in mindset, scope, and credibility.
We must thank the French Presidency for this, and we are well aware that it is not entirely unconnected to their efforts. Thank you, Mr. President.
The situation in Gaza is known to everyone.
what we are discussing here in Parliament is natural.

But we demand that the Security Council take a position, we demand that the relevant bodies take a position, that the European Union take a position. And we, in Parliament, debate and are unwilling to take a position.

I believe that, even so, given the urgency of the situation in Gaza, it is of utmost importance that this Parliament take a stance and state precisely what it intends to do to halt the massacres currently taking place in the Middle East.
I find it unacceptable that this Parliament has not mustered the courage and clarity of mind to pass a resolution following our debate.
That is why our group requests that the decision of the Conference of Presidents be revised and that the debate we must conclude be completed.
to have a position on the situation in Gaza through a resolution that will demonstrate this Parliament’s clear and firm stance, by a majority, to ensure the cessation of massacres in Gaza.

We want a resolution; we must be aware that we have a political responsibility regarding what is happening, and this political responsibility cannot simply be a discussion—it must be a resolution that clearly states what we want and what we denounce.
Mr. President, Commissioner, more than ever, the draft directive that Parliament is about to vote on evokes in me a very mixed feeling.
It is true that the rapporteur, Mr. Klins, has for years conducted extensive work and that he has negotiated with skill, particularly during the trilogue.

It is also true that the directive has seen a number of significant advancements toward better functioning of the internal market, collective management of financial assets, and is welcomed as such by the European investment funds industry.

It remains the case that debates and discussions within the Council and Parliament were never entirely free, since the results were known in advance for certain actors. It was, at all costs, necessary to introduce the European passport for management companies.
In principle, there is nothing to criticize; the passport holds up very well. It is still necessary to ensure that the introduction of a passport for management companies...
It is accompanied by necessary guarantees, particularly regarding the supervision of funds, as it results in a dissociation of functions beyond borders.
Alternatively, I observe with regret that the system in place is not only complex, but also susceptible to divergent interpretations.
It is likely to soon encounter practical difficulties that will harm the European industry, particularly exports to third-party countries.
I have taken note of the fact that my position is in the minority, however, I do not feel uncomfortable.
Normally, I would have been inclined to say that only practice will allow for definitive conclusions to be drawn in the matter and therefore to determine
Who is right: those who trust in the adaptive capacities of market actors, or those who adhere to a more cautious approach?
It is not excluded that success lies ahead, but on the other hand, nothing guarantees it either.
Or, very recent events, notably the Madoff scandal and its implications for the financial collective asset management industry, are not designed to reassure us.
Skepticism is followed by my concern.
The investment fund industry will not be spared by the financial crisis, we are witnessing this already.
It may be that fundamental reevaluations are necessary, that from this context of crisis

The fact that, within this context of profound crisis, we are making choices that dilute the responsibilities of actors or that presuppose perfect cooperation between supervisory authorities can genuinely be seen as an incongruity.
I tell you as I think: this directive is also that of a bygone era, preceding the crisis.
She is marked by a certain nonchalance.
Indeed, the financial system is poised to experience a lasting and fundamental crisis of confidence, and entire segments of its architecture must be rethought.

Let us not forget that the primary function of OCPMs is to protect the investor through risk diversification and the establishment of strict rules. By voting on this text as it stands, without truly knowing where we are going, we are proceeding as if nothing, absolutely nothing, had happened.
This autism portends nothing good, which is why I will abstain even though I have signed the compromise amendments negotiated with the Council.
Given the circumstances, the improvements introduced do indeed appear to be of little significance in the face of the fundamental questions I have just outlined.

Mr. President, although the regulation on animal reporting has been in force since January 2007, it appears that Member States are not consistently complying by providing, as requested, annual reports.
Consequently, a comprehensive analysis remains inherently random, given the numerous missing elements concerning the resources allocated to conduct inspections.
As a member of animal protection associations and a member of the animal welfare intergroup, this subject concerns me particularly.
Associations have been desperately campaigning for decades, only to see guidelines established in the year 2007 in this area, where Member States display a certain degree of leniency.
I would even venture to say a certain unwillingness, for, after all, we know that the implementation of controls and inspections is not insurmountable.
We know the slaughter locations, we know the rearing locations, we know the transit routes of livestock. So, where is the problem?

I believe that in our era, where public opinion is increasingly, and rightfully, attuned to animal welfare, whether concerning farming conditions, slaughtering practices, or transportation, states must respect these sentiments.
Since I have been given the floor, I would like to add, regarding transportation, that it would be essential to consider, independently of transportation times, the local climatic conditions.
Indeed, a multi-hour transport in the Netherlands in spring is not comparable to the same transport time in full summer in a country such as Greece.
Should night-time transport not be mandated in these latter cases?
Thank you for considering this proposal in the future.

I am pleased that it is a Briton, our colleague Parish, who has submitted this text, as if the Roman soldiers, two thousand years ago, did well to go to Great Britain and bring amphorae of olive oil and wine.
But then, two consequences must be drawn from this.

It is not very reasonable, symbolically, to locate the food agency in Helsinki, and it is not reasonable that the European Commission does not reconsider the following points: first, reinstate subsidies for almond growers; second, halt the

halt the attacks being perpetrated against olive trees, particularly in Andalusia and throughout Europe, halt the attacks being perpetrated against bluefin tuna fishermen in the Mediterranean, and halt the attacks being perpetrated against the European vineyard through uprooting.
I suggest to our commissioner, to our president, Mr. Barroso, to organize a grand banquet in Portugal with sheep’s cheeses and wine from
We have indeed all advocated for the closure of Guantanamo, and we all welcome President Obama’s decision to close this prison of shame.
Today, the question of welcoming Guantanamo detainees should not arise for us.
As Europeans faithful to our values of defending human rights, we must take our responsibilities, for it is our duty to welcome these former detainees.
And we were able to read—and here I address the Council—that some Member States were not particularly keen on this reception.
I would genuinely like to issue a call to the Council and, in particular, to the hesitant Member States, to accept these detainees on their territory.

And I will tell you, dear colleagues, that the worst thing would be for the admirable momentum generated by the closure of Guantanamo to falter because we failed to respond when Europe called upon us.

It is important because the European animal feed sector constitutes one of the most significant sectors of agriculture, both in terms of production—representing half of agricultural production within the European Union, 120 million tonnes—and in terms of turnover, approximately 50 billion euros.
The European Union, in fact, comprises five million livestock farmers and sixty million households owning pets.

In the past, the European Union has had to manage a number of health crises, which means that today, we must be more vigilant regarding transparency to meet the expectations of both farmers and consumers.

The provisions outlined in this report have the advantage of representing minimal cost for industries and substantial benefit for consumers, who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they purchase.

The adoption of this report will help limit risks by ensuring improved product quality, enhanced control, greater traceability, and comprehensive information for the farmer, and ultimately, the consumer.
Today, with the increase in international exchanges, it is more than imperative to strengthen any preventative measures so that the food crises we have experienced in the past are not repeated.

This report manages to reconcile the right to information with the strict definition of nutritional elements that must obligatorily appear on labels, and the right to intellectual property, so vital for preserving the competitiveness of our industries.

I believe that, indeed, manufacturers should be obligated to immediately notify the use of any new raw material entering into the composition of animal feed in order to guarantee transparency and facilitate control carried out by the competent authorities.
Including an emergency procedure that allows for the introduction of a new hazardous substance into the list of prohibited materials appears to me entirely indispensable.

Similarly, granting the breeder the possibility of questioning the competent national authority or the European Commission in case of doubt regarding a misleading claim helps to better secure the system, protecting the customer while preserving the fairness of commercial transactions.

I would therefore like to offer my full support to this excellent report, because experience shows that regulation regarding the labeling of animal feed—I conclude, Mr. President—prioritizing quality, transparency, traceability, and control is the best guarantee for preventing new health crises in Europe.

Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, it is certainly not Europe, nor its High Representative for Foreign Affairs, Javier Solana, former Secretary General of NATO, who can play the role of mediator between Israel and the Palestinians.
At most, they are called upon to finance the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, as they do today for Kosovo, Lebanon, or Afghanistan?
Americans and Israelis bomb, Europeans finance reconstruction.
This is the division of labor among allies.
Or, it would be necessary for those who are breaking things to pay.
Egypt is at the center of peace talks concerning an extended ceasefire with Hamas.

But the challenge to be met is formidable, as the new Israeli government, under pressure from the third man, Liberman, leader of a far right that is democratically accepted there, risks seeing its task singularly complicated in this negotiation.
Indeed, Netanyahu, who is presented as the future Prime Minister, has consistently opposed a truce with Hamas.
Another difficulty is that Mahmoud Abbas's Palestinian Authority has become in the West Bank a kind of international protectorate whose legitimacy has greatly diminished among the population.
The final element to consider is the expansion of Israeli settlements, which has never ceased since 1967, rendering the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank particularly delicate.
Today, the ball is in the Israeli camp, but do the hawks on both sides accept this truce of God that both parties demand without providing the means to achieve it?
Allow me to add a thought regarding France’s reintegration into NATO’s integrated military structure, which will be debated in light of the Vatanen report.
This reintegration will impose severe obligations on France.
Indeed, we are rejoining NATO while the Cold War has ended for ninety years.
Sarkozy appears to have forgotten the fall of the Berlin Wall and Russia’s return to the ranks of free nations.
Should the logic of blocs be strengthened at a time when multipolarization and the rise of emerging countries—including militarily—are occurring?
Furthermore, France’s accession to the integrated structure will obligate it to bolster its contingent in Afghanistan, even though it already has three personnel deployed there.
With what budget will she then finance this, when her defense budget is to fall below two percent of GDP and more than thirty regiments are to be eliminated?
Paradoxically, we will increase our budgetary contribution to join NATO while simultaneously reducing our military presence in Africa.
European defense, dear to President Sarkozy, will therefore be a pillar of the Atlantic alliance.
It sufficed to read the Treaty of Lisbon and its additional protocols to be convinced of this.
Whether in matters of foreign policy or common security, the European path is a dead end that will lead only to alignment with the Americans and their allies.
It is this logic of erasure that we reject in the name of national sovereignty and independence, relying in particular on our autonomous nuclear deterrent.
Madam President, I congratulate our three rapporteurs on this quite remarkable synthesis they have produced of the current state of our foreign policy and common security policy.

Mr. High Representative, you know better than anyone that Europe is expected today on the world stage to take the place that its economic and demographic power, and the richness of its democratic and humanist values, assign to it.

It must be noted that despite the consistent desire expressed by over two-thirds of our European citizens—as you yourself have stated—certain progress has undoubtedly been made over the last ten years; I concede this. However, it must be noted that this Europe does not yet exist.
If an illustration were needed, a recent one at that, to demonstrate his removal from the solution to the new drama in the Middle East, I would be here to prove it.
There has been, and always will be, a need for European presence in Gaza to play an active role, both in assisting the survival of the population and the reconstruction of the
within the country and in the fight against the smuggling of weapons that had made it possible to transform this territory into a launch base for rockets of all calibers.
Despite the kind words lavished upon Charmeltier and Jerusalem, nothing has yet been done in this regard.

I reiterate here a question already raised during the Lebanese crisis: when, Mr. High Representative, can we hope for the deployment of a European fleet in the Mediterranean, as we have deployed one to counter piracy?
We have the means.
Will we ever have the will?
Well, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President, dear colleagues, the Parliament's decision to accept the urgency requested by the Council for the
The handling of this file has been unanimous, both at the fisheries commission last week and this morning, here in plenary session.
We are indeed all aware of the necessity for the European Union to honor the commitments made in Marrakech last November by the competent international committee, the CICTA.
This specifically concerns giving effect to the recommendations adopted by this organization in order to curb the persistent overfishing of bluefin tuna in the
In the Eastern Atlantic and in the Mediterranean, and to confront the serious dangers that result from this for the future of the species and therefore that of the fishery itself.
Two of our colleagues from the Fisheries Commission, Ms. Fraga and Mr. Romeva i Rueda, were present in Marrakech and will speak about it as part of this debate.
For my part, I would like to reiterate the importance that our committee attaches to this file, which concerns the principal dimensions of the common fisheries policy, namely management
the resource, fleet management, compliance with international, regional, and bilateral agreements, technical measures, and above all, control—I will return to that shortly.
This characteristic dossier, therefore, appears to us as a test of the credibility of this common fisheries policy.
For this reason, it was obviously out of the question that the implementation of the new recovery plan would proceed without consultation of the European Parliament.
I am therefore pleased that the Commission has finally chosen the only path legally and politically acceptable for the implementation of the directive.
recommendations of the CCTV, namely that of a formal settlement proposal, based on Article Thirty-Seven of the Treaty.

The transposition into Community law of commitments made by the Commission on behalf of the European Union within regional fisheries organizations is, in fact, not a trivial operation, and we insist that it always be carried out under the democratic control of our institution.
Essentially, I welcome the various measures proposed, which, although demanding for our operators, are commensurate with the challenges at stake, and I emphasize that the most significant
The most important of these measures are certainly those that will concern control, for it is true that without control, no plan of restoration can demonstrate effectiveness.
I therefore thank you, Mr. Commissioner, for this proposal and invite you to demonstrate as much
determination in the concrete implementation of the plan, once it has been endorsed by the Council, as you demonstrated in reaching an agreement satisfactory at the CICTA level.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I regret that the Council and the Commission have yet to undertake a concrete definition of territorial cohesion.
The French presidency attempted this, and I wish to commend this initiative.
Our Parliament continues to insist that this objective be applicable from the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty and that its contours be clarified as soon as possible.

I wish, in the manner of the excellent report by Mr. Van Nistelrooy, that territorial cohesion should become the legal basis guaranteeing the harmonious development of all the territories of the Union and enabling the fullest possible exploitation of the specific characteristics of each European region.
It is essential to better coordinate community policies in order to maximize the impact of interventions in the field.
Territorial cohesion is not intended to target exclusively regions experiencing permanent disadvantages.
It must nevertheless focus on the polycentric development of the European Union as a whole, taking into account the characteristics of each territory while preserving their diversity.
This new concept appears relevant for taking into account the outermost regions to ensure them sustainable and balanced growth.

In this regard, I thank the rapporteur for having incorporated in his compromise amendments my requests concerning the specific challenges faced by outermost regions in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, essential elements of territorial cohesion.
Upon reading the recent communication from the Commission, entitled RUPs: An Asset for Europe, it appears to me that it intends to apply the entirety of the
recommendations concerning the improvement of governance in cohesion matters, thereby making RUPs the first, albeit somewhat premature, illustration of the implementation of territorial cohesion.

I hope that the Overseas General Assembly, which will soon begin in France, proceeds in the same manner and incorporates the significant territorial impact of European policies supporting Regional and Urban Funds (RUB), the added value of which is undeniable.
and undeniable.
One enjoys reading the conclusions of the presidency of the last Council.
It reads like a victory communiqué from all defeated armies.

They display a paltry attitude, even in the reiterated claim that, as the crisis ends, the EU will build a stronger economy for the future, or in the reaffirmation of a Lisbon strategy in full disarray.
Thus, as they confine themselves within their glass tower, Eurocrats, Europhiles, and all manner of Europeans ultimately lose sight of the bigger picture.
Everyone is well aware that the eurozone was the first to enter a recession, having experienced the lowest deficit rate globally for eight years.
But it is also the one facing the greatest difficulties regarding its industrial competitiveness and the employment situation.
Above all, it is she who, through the general disarmament of the natural defenses stripped from nations, is the least equipped to react.
In reality, the sole merit of this crisis will be to awaken peoples lulled by the conveniences of financial anticipation and by nationalist propaganda.
Only states will possess the legitimate instruments necessary for any significant action and will, for that reason, need to challenge the constraints of the EU and the euro.
For the French, at any rate, it is increasingly clear that there will be no salvation without France, no France without French policy, no French policy without national and popular sovereignty.

Madam President, I believe that the question of distributing food supplies to benefit the most vulnerable is indeed timely, but I believe that, at its core, the Commission’s proposal does not address the issue.
The question of co-financing concerns me, and I believe the issue is rather the prevalence of liberalism in the evaluation of the CAP in recent years that needs to be challenged.
Riots against hunger, the abrupt fluctuations in food prices, are persistent indicators of the limits of agricultural market liberalization.
This liberalization has always come at the expense of vulnerable populations, vulnerable producers, and vulnerable territories.

I therefore argue for policy to reclaim its authority, to take control, both at the European and global levels, and that the strategic domain of agriculture and human food, both quantitatively and qualitatively, should not be subject to the strict laws of the market.
Indeed, there is a sense of urgency, and the Sikorski report addresses this urgency, which I welcome, but I wish that, within the framework of the reflection that is opening up on
Regarding the future of the CAP, it should be recalled that the priority objective remains to structurally combat hunger and poverty as we know them in all Member States and throughout the world.
Rural territories are available to meet food needs with sufficient and quality production; however, they must be given the financial and human resources to fulfill this weighty responsibility.
Mr. President, in this period of economic recession, it was important that the European Union continue to demonstrate its solidarity towards developing countries.
Let us recall that in 2007, the European Community and its Member States jointly accounted for sixty percent of total development aid, making the European Union the world’s leading donor.
European development funds enable the fight against poverty while promoting economic development and democracy.

I am therefore pleased that a budget of twenty-three billion euros has been allocated for ACP countries for the period 2008-2013 under the 10th EDF, which represents practically double the amount provided for the 9th EDF.
The French Court of Accounts, in its report, concludes that the accounts of the 7th, 8th, and 9th European Regional Development Funds are, generally speaking, faithful, legal, and regular.
One can only commend the record levels of contract execution and disbursement of funds for the European Regional Development Fund.
However, I also note that progress must continue to strengthen the control and monitoring system, as a significant level of errors continues to affect certain transactions.
Similarly, there is a risk that is too often overestimated in the context of budgetary support, and it is, in my opinion, advisable to better assess these risks.
On this matter, I share the view that budgetary support should be granted only if the beneficiary country has the capacity to manage funds transparently, responsibly, and effectively.

Among the priorities on which we must work in the future, I would like to mention the integration of the FED into the general budget—I will conclude my remarks regarding the community—as this would strengthen the effectiveness and transparency of development assistance.

To conclude, Mr. President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, the representatives of the Court, but also all the Commission staff who have done excellent work on site, and I obviously regret the absence of the Council, and in particular the Czech Presidency.
Madam President, Parliament and its rapporteur were compelled to reject a flawed compromise, and they were right to do so.
Our delegation remained faithful to the position adopted overwhelmingly in plenary session, which called for the eventual elimination of all exemptions from the legal working week.
But the truth is that Parliament was the only body wishing to move things forward.
The representatives of the European people had decided far beyond partisan divisions to end this anachronism known as the opt-out.
We were the only ones to propose a genuine compromise text, which the Council of Ministers superbly ignored, as did the Commission.
The Council and the Commission have aligned themselves with the position of those who fiercely oppose any advancement of workers' rights in Europe.
Mr. President of the Council, it is clear that you have achieved your objectives.
The Court of Justice requires you to consider all custody time as working time; therefore, you have lost nothing in that regard.
The opt-out you desire still exists in practice; the status quo has therefore prevailed.
More than ever, the deputies elected next June will have to strive for a top-down harmonization of social standards.
Sir.

Mr. President, this is certainly not on behalf of the liberated Commission, but likely on behalf of my group. I would like to take this brief minute to express my extraordinarily positive appreciation for Ms. Pagano’s report.
Congratulations, Madam, on your report.

I believe that in writing this report, you have developed an extraordinarily precise specification of elements that should rightfully feature prominently, Mr. Commissioner, in the Stockholm Programme, of which I know the Commission is actively preparing.

Allow me to add to everything that has been said concerning the importance of judicial training, the importance of evaluation, and to emphasize two fundamental elements in terms of mutual trust which form the basis of what could be tomorrow’s mutual recognition.
one, the independence of the judiciary.
Currently, within the Union, there are several countries in which the independence of the judiciary from political power or from other powers has not been established.
It is a scandal, and this scandal must end.
Two, procedural guarantees.

As long as we are not certain that in a number of countries, individuals suspected or accused of committing certain types of offenses benefit from procedural safeguards analogous to those existing in other countries, it is difficult to secure widespread acceptance of the principle of mutual recognition.
It is a fundamental element, and I wanted to introduce it into this debate.
Congratulations, Madame Pagano.
Madam President, we cannot remain silent about the situation in Madagascar, and we will not be alone in condemning it.

The African Union, the Southern African Development Community, the International Organization of the Francophonie, the Inter-Parliamentary Union, the European Union in the voice of the Commission, the

The USA, a significant number of countries, including my own and Norway, to speak of countries on the European continent, have condemned the coup d'état, because one must call a spade a spade, which took place in Madagascar.
We cannot remain silent and we are calling for a return to constitutional legality.
We never demand a return to square one, with, if necessary, arbitration by the Malagasy people through a consultation in the form of a presidential election or referendum.
It is incumbent upon the assemblies and political leaders of Madagascar to determine the most effective form of consultation.
What we are requesting with this joint resolution is to add our voice to that of the international community to clearly signal to those who have seized power in a wholly unacceptable manner.

democratic and in the form of a coup d'état, however cleverly disguised, to return to the constitutional legality of Madagascar, which is one of the guarantees of the future development of this great island in the Indian Ocean.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, naturally, I would like to thank Commissioner Dimas for his presence and his responses, for the continued attention he gives to all these disasters.
We worked together extensively when President Barroso had asked me to prepare a report, which he subsequently cited, on the creation of a European civil protection force.
This report, I presented it on May ninth, two thousand six, and
When I reread it and see all the catastrophes that have occurred, I think it remains remarkably relevant.
Madame Zavella, of course, there is more to it than Greece.
All countries are affected. I would add that there are not only natural disasters, but also human disasters, caused by humans.
I think of maritime disasters, the Erika and how many others, and industrial accidents of the Chernobyl type.
There are other natural disasters besides wildfires.
I am thinking about the tsunami.
We may one day fear a tsunami in the Mediterranean, as there was one at the beginning of the 20th century that utterly destroyed the city of Messina.
Frankly, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the tools we mobilize are not up to the scale of these disasters that will multiply under the combined effect of global warming and transportation.
And that’s why I believe we need to be more ambitious.
I thank the Commission, Commissioner Dimas, all their teams, and the Directorate-General that operates the civil protection mechanism.
I believe we need to go further.
created with member countries that wish to participate, one can imagine enhanced cooperation.
If we are not twenty-seven to form this civil defense unit, let's start with twelve or fifteen.
And then you will see that it will concern everyone.
When I list disasters, I can say that everyone is affected: the floods that struck Germany in two thousand two, major pandemics, and terrorism.
There you have it, Commissioner, why I would like the Commission to take the initiative to go further, to propose to the Member States that they go further.
Our Parliament, the Environment Committee, and the Defense and Security Committee will support you in these voluntary initiatives.

Mr. President, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, Members of Parliament, once again this summer, the Mediterranean forest has been ravaged by flames in Marseille, in Southern Corsica, but also in Italy, in Spain, and, on a larger scale, in Greece.
More than four hundred hectares of forests and fields have gone up in smoke, provoking considerable material debates, irreparable damage to biodiversity, and dramatic losses of human lives.
Deeply dismayed by this recurring record year after year and aware of the multiplier effect of global warming on fires,
I call for a European awareness-raising effort to improve coordination and pool resources for firefighting.
I wish to see realized an extensive Euro-Mediterranean cooperation project for combating forest fires within the framework of the Union for the Mediterranean.
I commend existing initiatives, notably the European Forest Fire Information System, pilot project,

Nevertheless, I call for a reform of the European Union’s Solidarity Fund so that it becomes a high-performing tool for responding to crises and a strengthening of the European Union’s rapid response capability.
and of the Euro Aid scheme conceived by Michel Barnier as early as 2006 to intervene within the territory of the twenty-seven member states as well as abroad.

I believe that one of the keys to the problem of wildfires lies in the exchange of knowledge and best practices regarding prevention, and I would like to highlight the pioneering role played by forest firefighters in my own department.
and I can readily place this example, which may be useful, at Europe’s disposal.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I will be brief.
I believe there are two elements in this debate.
The conjuncture question: how to exit this crisis?
All measures that both assist farmers and involve intervention are necessary and absolutely essential.
They must be supported and even considered more important.
This is what we are proposing with a number of colleagues here in Parliament.
Secondly, there is a question posed in a structural manner regarding the management of the milk market, and it is there that there is a divergence with you, Madam Commissioner.
You propose moving towards contractualization.
I am telling you in advance that formalizing agreements between industrialists and farmers, with industries being competitive amongst themselves, will result in competition on a European scale.
We require, in order to regulate a market, public regulation.
There is no other alternative.
That is where the debate will need to begin following this crisis.
I believe that on this particular debate, all opinions and all options must be respected, and I fear that we moved too quickly during the health assessment to resolve a matter such as quotas.

So far, I am saying to all those who have intervened, it has allowed both to maintain dairy production in Europe, to ensure a highly developed dairy industry, and at the same time, to secure a consumer price that has been, until now, quite manageable. Thank you, Madam Commissioner.
Mr. President, just a few days after the positive referendum in Ireland, I genuinely feel that we can say we are, today, more European than we were before.
I genuinely rejoiced, peacefully.
Unfortunately, we remain essentially dependent on the decision of the Constitutional Court, but also on the goodwill of the Czech president.

A clear signal of accountability must be sent to those who hold the future of this treaty in their hands, a treaty that is vital for the Union, for our institutions, and for the five hundred million Europeans that we represent.
We can no longer be held hostage by a few whose sole aim is to thwart the broader European interest.
It is legitimate for some to wish not to go further in European integration, it is legitimate to express these reservations, but it is also legitimate to allow those who desire it to progress.
Generally, the processes of ratifying European treaties too often take the form of sagas or victories snatched at the last moment.
Are we condemned to constantly having to force the implementation of a treaty and its institutional reforms?
We must draw lessons from this chaotic ratification process and also, obviously, from this engagement in negotiations aimed at organizing a second
referendum in Ireland, as if it were normal to re-vote a people who have expressed themselves sovereignly, and as if it were normal for an assent to a treaty to be a bargaining chip.
It concerns the coherence and institutional balance of the European endeavor.
Ratifying a treaty is a minimal requirement of loyalty and cohesion from the moment one chooses that one’s country adheres to the European Union.
We wanted to send a strong signal to citizens by ratifying the treaty for the European elections of June two thousand nine.
What do you think the citizen believes today regarding the Treaty of Lisbon, and beyond our internal cohesion and legitimacy?
Mr. President, my intervention concerns the deterioration of working conditions in Europe.
Today, nearly half of the world’s workers earn less than two dollars a day.
Twelve point three million people are still subjected to slavery and more than two hundred million children are forced to work.
In Europe, the number of working poor is increasing day after day, and the International Labour Organization counts one hundred and sixty deaths annually linked to a lack of prevention.
In this context, I would like to emphasize our responsibility towards all those who are deprived of employment and social rights, who work in conditions that are unworthy.
of these millions of workers who suffer morally and physically, sometimes driven to suicide or victims of cancers or chronic illnesses due to their working conditions.
It is time to move beyond the religion of working more, the pursuit of profit, and short-term competition.
The right to decent work and the strengthening of the right to work must be at the forefront of the Union’s priorities over the next ten years.
Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, a challenge for humanity, a challenge for future generations.

To rise to the challenge, Copenhagen must allow for a global agreement, a single agreement, as our Committee on the Environment Chair, Jolainen Hui, will explain shortly; a coalition of all industrialized and emerging nations is necessary.

Today, with our debate, but also with the drafting of a resolution by our Parliament, we are once again calling on the European Union to maintain its leading role in this necessary policy of combating climate change.
Let us recall that it is fitting that we speak with one voice to maintain our credibility.
Yes, we must reach an agreement in Copenhagen to limit the increase in the global average temperature to a level that does not exceed two degrees above pre-industrial levels.
Yes, we must, in Copenhagen, sign an agreement to achieve collective emissions reductions of thirty percent by 2020 compared to 1990.
But that will not be enough.
It is not only necessary for developed countries to substantially reduce their emissions, but also that developing countries contribute to achieving the goals.

Industrialized countries must, therefore, provide sufficient, sustainable, and predictable financial and technical support to developing countries to encourage them to commit to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions.
Copenhagen must therefore enable developing countries to transition towards low-carbon models.
Also, allow me to address two avenues that seem necessary for our future.
First, the global implementation of climate change mitigation funding based on the taxation of financial transactions.
Subsequently, it seems necessary to me to implement a fiscal adjustment at the borders of Europe that would target imports of products manufactured without any regard for environmental protection.

a contractualization and the reversal to Southern countries of the carbon tax thus collected at Europe’s borders, and which would serve to finance investments in the equipment necessary for combating global warming.

Mr. President, I would like to speak along the same lines as my intervention yesterday regarding the preparation for the Copenhagen summit and following, moreover, yesterday’s ECOFIN meeting, which was not a success.
I raised the issue with you regarding the responsibility we, as industrialized nations, have to ensure that developing countries can keep pace with our efforts to combat climate change.
In Copenhagen, we cannot pretend that we all have the same capabilities, otherwise that would mean that we are all starting from the same point to ultimately achieve nothing.

To convince our development partners to join us, it will obviously be necessary to address the question of the assistance that must be provided to them and not wait for the outcome of the Copenhagen summit.
At the upcoming European Council, the twenty-seven must absolutely agree on how the European Union envisions aid to developing countries within the significant context of climate change.
Yesterday, as I was saying, the Eurogroup of finance ministers failed to reach a common position on this issue.
Yet, we know that this question is absolutely central.
The European Commission had already made proposals, but I absolutely wish that we take the lead in guiding our partners towards a global solidarity necessary to overcome this climate change problem.
I commend the efforts of the Swedish presidency to achieve an ambitious agreement in Copenhagen, despite the strong wind of pessimism blowing over these future negotiations.
For my part, I believe that conceding at this stage that the Copenhagen summit is lackluster or that it will not result in a conclusive agreement ratified by all parties does not demonstrate realism.
Let us not succumb too readily to pessimism.
I advocate that at this juncture, we do not scale back our ambitions, neither in terms of objectives nor in terms of timelines.
We must continue to believe in a comprehensive, ambitious, and legally binding global political agreement, paving the way for the conclusion of a legally sound treaty as soon as possible.
It is truly too early to discuss the deadline of the COP of December sixteenth, two thousand ten.
We must now translate our rhetoric into genuine political will.
We must clarify our commitment in financial terms and assistance to developing countries, particularly regarding technology transfer.
At this stage, a total and collective commitment from the European Union is indispensable.

I also note on paper the recent, yet exemplary, impetus given to discussions by Brazil, South Korea, Indonesia, and Norway in particular, who have quantified their ambitions to reduce their polluting emissions.

While we can understand the flexibility sought by the United States, which is only beginning to consider the climate question, we must nonetheless arrive at quantified, binding, and ambitious commitments in the short, medium, and long term, from other major polluters like the United States and China.
Failing that, we rush toward climate, political, and moral disaster.
Madam President, we all know and we have all said the importance of the Copenhagen negotiations, but if we all hope for an agreement, we cannot accept an agreement at any price.
If the conditions for an ambitious agreement are not met, I wish to state very clearly that the European Union must be capable of saying no and refusing to sign a watered-down agreement.
The European populations we represent here expect an agreement, an agreement that will allow us to effectively combat all the climatic disruptions we observe daily around us.
They will not settle for mere advertising effects, unquantified statements of intent, or non-binding objectives upon which one can simply walk away once the media spotlight has faded.

In Copenhagen, the states must commit. The European Union, the only continent to have seen its CO₂ emissions decrease in ninety years, the only continent to forecast specific, binding, and ambitious commitments for the future, cannot shoulder the burden of the effort alone.

That is why, if other industrialized and emerging countries do not wish to shoulder their share of the burden, we must draw all the necessary consequences by establishing at our borders a tax protecting our industry from the competition of those who decide not to participate in a global agreement.
We, Europeans, demand a little more each day from our industrialists.
I would like the climate package that was signed during the French presidency as evidence.

I would like to see proof of this in the national initiatives that, like the carbon tax praised earlier by Mr. Parniaud – and I applaud this – are driving the establishment of an ecological tax system.

A sector such as transportation, which is among the largest emitters of CO₂, even if certain modes of transport, like aviation, emit fewer greenhouse gases, is increasingly contributing to the fight against climate change.
Or, it is a sector that has been very heavily impacted by the fallout from the crisis.

If, as I hope, maritime and air transport are integrated into the negotiations in Copenhagen, then let us ensure that what is asked of European industries will also be asked of those in other industrialized countries.
In Copenhagen, world public opinion will have eyes fixed on us and we will call upon you diligently. Please complete [the task], do not disappoint us. Thank you.
Madam President, dear colleagues, the Copenhagen summit is a historic opportunity to change the course of the planet.
We must arrive at decisions even more binding than those made in Kyoto.
We too must call for the creation of an international organization, such as the WTO, tasked with regulating climate change and environmental issues, and to create a fund
in addition, of course, to public development aid, to create a maritime and aviation carbon tax, as we must also do on financial transactions.
We clearly see the pressing need for global regulation of the environment, as well as of financial markets and the internet.
We have the opportunity to open this historical trajectory through the environment.
Let us do so in the image of our highest human aspirations, otherwise we shall appear as actors with no grasp of reality. Thank you.

Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, dear colleagues, less than two weeks before the Copenhagen conference, concerns are growing regarding the success of climate change negotiations.
Some, indeed, are already saying that it will be a failure.
Major global powers are still reluctant to demonstrate the full ambition that the climate emergency demands of them.

By adopting tomorrow the draft resolution on the European Union's strategy ahead of the Copenhagen Conference, we, Members of the European Parliament, must demonstrate that our resolve is first and foremost absolute, and that the conference must result in an agreement that is indeed precise but, above all, binding.
Furthermore, the binding nature of this agreement, once found, must not be open to challenge or question.

We cannot indefinitely postpone the decision to tomorrow, lest it be too late; hence the necessary creation of a global environmental organization, which appears today not only necessary but also urgent, as it will, under the auspices of the UN, be responsible for overseeing the implementation of the commitments made in Copenhagen.
We must, from Copenhagen onwards, be able to expect greater lucidity and responsibility from this world.
I would like to express my support for the joint initiative of the British socialist government and the French government aimed at returning Afghans in an irregular situation to their territory.
Indeed, contrary to what some have said, these individuals had seen their asylum applications rejected. This bilateral initiative must now be extended at the European level.
Migration pressure is a challenge that we must address collectively, and this is the purpose of the Pact on Immigration and Asylum adopted several months ago under the French presidency.
Now, we must move further by pooling our resources and organizing joint return flights financed by Frontex.

The decision of the twenty-seven Member States to request that the Commission conduct a study on this subject is a first step, and, Mr. Commissioner, I wish the Commission to support this proposal, as the fight against illegal immigration is an expectation of public opinion and, particularly, of immigrant populations in regular status.
Mr. President, I would like to revisit a recent event, the Swiss vote on minarets.
Indeed, this vote took place in a state that is not a member of the European Union, but it is evident that it concerns a matter that is not foreign to us.
I would like to revisit this event because I also see it as an opportunity to discuss secularism, and we never speak enough about secularism in this forum.
It is necessary and urgent that the principle of secularism governs the organization of our society, and I would like to say here some straightforward things.
First, the opposite principle of secularism is not religiosity, nor even less so, spirituality.

The principle contrary to secularism is religious communautarism, which dictates rules and laws superior to civil laws, the communautarism that confines individuals within groups subservient to society.
Our Union, through its history, is multicultural and multiethnic.
She will become increasingly so, and only secularism can allow individuals
The Caesar programme, which aims to modernize air traffic management in Europe, is a major project.

How will the Commission prepare the next phase of redeployment of the Caesar programme, and in particular the financing of this essential programme for the environment as for our scientific and technical influence?
The Commission will follow the recommendations of the report submitted in 2007, according to which a high-level, qualified personality should ensure the political oversight of this programme?

Indeed, it will require overcoming numerous legal, psychological, and technical obstacles, by unifying national airspaces and ensuring that air traffic controllers from different countries work together.
If Europe cannot unify its airspace, how will it be capable of building a strong political entity?
Mr. President, Madam Minister, dear colleagues, the importance of the issue of climate change is no longer in question.

These impacts, whether short, medium, or long term, are undeniable, even if today the results of the GESC in a certain national newspaper are making headlines and certainly reinforcing the positions of the skeptics.
The Copenhagen summit appeared to the world as a unique opportunity for world leaders to acknowledge, act, and rectify the effects of climate change.

The European Union was at the forefront of this discussion, not only due to the bold legislation that we have concerning the limitation of the impact of our activities on the climate, but also because Europe represents a union of countries that can truly make a difference.
Certainly, the outcome of the Copenhagen conference can only leave a taste of dissatisfaction, but I refuse to speak of failure.
The world has agreed on the issue of limiting temperature increases to two degrees, and this even for a country as reluctant as China.
Brazil has just enacted a law aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by nearly thirty-nine percent by the year 2020, in accordance with its commitments.
Many others have also demonstrated significant ambitions regarding greenhouse gas emission reduction targets.
I am thinking of Japan and Norway.
Furthermore, it is also important to highlight the very positive aspect of the consensus reached regarding the urgency of a mechanism for reducing emissions attributable to deforestation.
A specific and unanimous text was obtained regarding the implementation of the Direct Plus mechanism to reduce deforestation and thereby enable natural CO₂ storage.
Far from a binding agreement but clearly in line with a political accord, the outcome of Copenhagen should lead us to question the reasons for such disappointment.
I attended the Copenhagen conference, as did many of my colleagues, with the desire to participate, to help, and to witness a negotiating Europe, a leading Europe.
My disappointment was considerable, as Europe clearly did not have the place it deserved in the negotiations, particularly when it came to the European Parliament.
To assert itself, Europe must demonstrate greater strength on the matter.
The meeting of our ministers on the environment in Seville did not yield results; our representatives were uncertain, hesitant, and we remain divided on our objectives.
I hope that Madame Edegarde, bolstered by her proposals and commitments made before the Environment Commission, will be able to raise the ambitions of the European Union.

Thank you. I give the floor to Mr. Baudis. Dear colleagues, in order to escape the caricatures – and we have heard a few this morning – I would like to recall a few objective elements concerning Tunisia, a partner country of the European Union.

The social situation has evolved very favorably, with a spectacular increase in average income per capita and, now, the vast majority of Tunisians meet the criteria defining membership in the middle class.

More than 90% of Tunisians benefit from social coverage, and over a quarter of Tunisia’s budget is allocated to education, meaning that the country is among the first to have achieved the Millennium Development Goals regarding primary education.
Finally, Mr. Michel recalled a moment ago that the rights of women are recognized and guaranteed.
At the university, female students outnumber male students; forty percent of the professors are women, as are a quarter of the deputies, elected local officials, or journalists.
Many countries could envy such results.
Mr. President, the acts of fanatical criminals who killed Christians in Egypt cannot be attributed to an entire people and its government.
It would be unjust to hold Egypt and Egyptians accountable for this abominable massacre, the perpetrators of which will be tried.
Let us not conflate the acts of a criminal with the policy of a country, nor mix up fanatics with an entire population. Finally, when claiming to interpose
Between Egyptian Coptic Christians and their Muslim compatriots, we provide arguments to extremists who seek to portray Eastern Christians as agents of the West.
Excuse me, Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, what is happening in Greece, in Portugal, tomorrow in Spain or in Ireland is scandalous.

These very Anglo-Saxon agencies, which complacently recorded the dealings of rogues emitting and trading toxic assets and saw nothing coming, are now of the utmost severity towards the states that rushed to the aid of a financial sector that did not deserve it.

The crisis triggered by the irresponsibility of markets and banks, and this massive aid, are directly responsible for the worsening of deficits and public debt that these same markets now claim to sanction.
There you have it, the moralization of capitalism proclaimed by Mr. Sarkozy, the European Union, and the G twenty.

All that bankers have taken away from the crisis is that the taxpayer is an inexhaustible source of resources, profits, and insurance, as the rumor is that the magnitude of this panic stems from a major American bank that benefited from government assistance.

American and two hedge funds of the same nationality who want to profit both from the exorbitant interest rates imposed on Greece and from the CDS market, these insurance policies on state loans which themselves are the subject of independent speculation.
It will not suffice to regulate hedge funds, which you are reluctant to do, or the markets for derivative instruments, as Mr. Barnier proposes.
It is pointless to create a European economic government.
The twenty-seven are, in any case, in the same predicament, and solidarity is not an option.
It is the free global circulation of capital that must be questioned, otherwise there will be
Mr. President, less than fifteen of the original stock of bluefin tuna remain today.
Faced with such figures, the solution appeared obvious.
Nevertheless, we must not overlook the positions affected by the decisions that concern us today.
It must be recalled that CITES is not intended to prohibit fishing, but only the international trade of this fish, eighty percent of which is exported to Japan.

By conserving tuna, we are certainly protecting a species dangerously sought after, but we are also encouraging the continuation of a more balanced and sustainable fishing activity—a fishery intended for our domestic market and a source of employment.

I am in favor of listing red tuna in Annex I of CITES, and while I believe this decision will be positive, support from the Commission is needed to facilitate a profound restructuring of the fishing sector.
My question therefore concerns the modalities of this support.
France is requesting a stay of eighteen months, accompanied by financial measures, for the sailors and shipowners concerned by a trade ban.
What is the Commission's perspective on the matter?
Furthermore, my concern, like that of many of my colleagues, relates to fairness.
How can we ensure that vessels flying the flags of countries such as Tunisia, Libya, or others will apply the prohibition of international trade with a rigor comparable to our own?
What new control and sanction measures will be implemented?

The sustainability policy for our economic activities must be concrete, sometimes even unpopular in certain sectors, but I hope that the Commission and the Council do not lose sight of the adjustments necessary for the implementation of these measures.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, as the rapporteur has reported, this draft directive indeed follows a vote in Parliament, as you also recalled, Mr. Commissioner.
However, my group remains extremely critical of this proposal, as it risks backfiring on those we aim to support.
In seeking to lighten the burden on businesses, we risk depriving them of the conditions of transparency and trust essential to their management and the dynamism of their operations.
First, I believe it is necessary to be clear about thresholds and what is termed a microentity.
These are SMEs with more than ten employees and an annual turnover exceeding one million euros.
Regardless of the Member State, this represents a very large majority of businesses.
