Certainly, they may be local and have limited presence in the Community market, but that does not negate the necessity of presenting accounting rules for them.
Accounting rules—they will have to confront them each time they wish to deal with a bank, with partners, or sometimes negotiate with fiscal, economic, and social institutions.

At that point, accounting regulations will be imposed upon them, and they may have to pay more than they would for standard accounting in order to satisfy criteria they may not necessarily understand.
I do not see any advantage in imposing accounting obligations outside of a common framework for the European Union.
This is not simply a matter of competition; it is fundamentally a question of economic integration, of Community law, and of equal treatment for all businesses within the European Union.
That being said, it is evident that simplifying accounting requirements for SMEs is a necessity.
Three initiatives, moreover, are moving in that direction, whether it be the proposal we are discussing today or the IF international framework.
whether it be the revision of the fourth and seventh accounting directives for which the European Commission should shortly be putting forward proposals to us.
These proposals were promised to us for the year 2010; it appears they are being extended, but I do not believe this extension of the deadline is a sufficient reason for
to rush and do a half-hearted job, because these three proposals, while sharing the same objective, may not have the same articulation. It seems to me, Mr. Commissioner,

is clearer for businesses, by providing them with a single, comprehensive response that will allow them to reconcile the objective of simplifying obligations desired by all with the reality of the day-to-day lives of small businesses that need it.
The current problem is that the European Commission is dragging its feet in proposing a revision of these directives, and this is detrimental to our deliberations.

I therefore call on the European Commission to accelerate the dialogue on the issue of the exemption that is currently dividing both European institutions and economic circles, and to conduct an impact study.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and dear colleagues, as my colleague Elisabeth Morin Chartier and other colleagues have indicated, the violent storm Xintia struck several French regions on February twenty-seventh and twenty-eighth, resulting in fifty-three fatalities and substantial material damage.
The storm was of exceptional intensity, causing devastating floods along the French coastline.
Following Madeira, Europe is concerned once again.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadet, has been severely affected.
Three French departments have thus been declared a natural disaster area: Brittany, Poitou-Charentes, and the Loire Valley.
Faced with these disasters, the European Union must demonstrate its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not only through words and a resolution, but also and above all through financial assistance that we will be able to support the victims of these disasters.
Therefore, my colleague Christophe Béchut and I urge the European Commission to swiftly release the Union Solidarity Fund to assist the affected regions in coping with the damage.
This catastrophe demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier’s proposal to create a European civil intervention force.

Europeans must act collectively, as disasters are multiplying and affecting our European territories, particularly our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I too would like to congratulate our rapporteur, Jörg Leichtfried, for his text and his spirit of cooperation on this matter, and I particularly support what concerns his proposals on the funding of air security, since we are talking about air security here and not air safety.

It has been many years that our committee has been striving to have the principle accepted that stricter security measures must be borne by the Member States, and I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, security does not concern only travelers but concerns all citizens, and it is the responsibility of states to take measures to combat terrorism.
It is therefore not justifiable that air passengers alone should bear the responsibility for financing security measures in airports and on board aircraft.
This is all the more so because in modes of transport such as rail and maritime, states finance, depending on the case, partially or wholly, security measures.
I therefore believe that we must remain steadfast in our stance towards the Council and defend to the very end amendment thirty-two of the report adopted by our transport committee.
I had another point to address briefly.

Although I support the advances in non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe that the purpose of this directive is to establish a uniform and identical European system of security levies.
While obliging adherence to common rules, it is necessary to allow Member States to retain their current system of collecting fees.

Thus, in states such as Spain, Italy, or France, duties are voted on by Parliament and, in this case, it is the authority for judicial review of laws that must serve as the independent supervisory authority.
and that is the object of amendment forty, which I hope you will be numerous in supporting when we vote on it.
Mr. President, Commissioner, the report I am presenting to Parliament attempts to explain that, in the fight against global warming, agriculture has a role and a place to play.
Nature this week reminds us that volcanoes, in particular, can have a major impact on human activities and on the climate.
However, this still necessitates that men, and Europe in particular, take responsibility for combating what is known as global warming.
My report attempts to demonstrate that agriculture can simultaneously continue to decrease its carbon emissions, reduce its consumption of fossil fuels, and, above all, on the other hand,
it actively participated in carbon sequestration to globally reduce emissions and increase fixed and sequestered carbon.
This report attempts to demonstrate that in agriculture, a shift is needed from a compartmentalized approach—one where a directive is opened each time a problem arises—
On the soils, on the water, on the pesticides, what else, and to attempt to address the agricultural question with the ambition of treating it globally, systemically.

In this approach, we must be able to identify avenues to ensure that agriculture, as I mentioned earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption but also actively contributes to carbon sequestration.

It is particularly the role related to photosynthesis, biomass, and, above all, what is important to me, also linked to the soil, to this capacity that European soils have to sequester organic carbon.

I believe that this line of inquiry I am opening in this report, and which I hope will be followed during the vote that will take place in plenary session in Brussels, should allow European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability, to ensure a

to this agriculture that would put it ahead of a number of other continents or other agricultural systems, ensuring its ability to be economically viable, ecologically effective, and I believe also, from that point onward, socially effective.

This report addresses a specific issue—the fight against global warming and agriculture—but it aspires, I hope, to open up other perspectives to inform, in particular, the debate concerning the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
I address the Commission, I will address it, and I have often done so with agricultural committees; I will also address the various ministers when I have the opportunity.
I believe we need to make a turn.
It is essential that this CAP of 2013 be ambitious.
She must rely on objectives that allow citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because Europe’s agriculture must ensure both food security and commit to the path of sustainability.
This is, in any case, what I propose in this report and what I hope the Parliament, in a large majority, will follow.

Mr. President, I would first like to emphasize that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments in closing their airspace in a targeted and temporary manner was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our citizens must take precedence over any other consideration, and under these circumstances, the attitude of certain airlines who are demanding the total and immediate reopening of airspace based on one or two test flights appears, to say the least, indecent.
It was Mr. Hennin, earlier, who spoke of the complementarity of modes of transport, particularly with the train, and I will seize the opportunity to say how much I regret that the aerial paralysis
has been exacerbated in certain countries, such as France, by the disorganization of rail transport, attributable to strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
Returning to our subject, I wish to commend the Commission's decision to authorize the granting of public aid to airlines affected by the current disruptions.
It is a common-sense decision in a context already marked by crisis, but these measures must be exceptional in nature.

In this regard, I wish that among the criteria retained for their granting, the exemplary nature demonstrated by companies in the compensation allocated to their clients who were victims of flight cancellations be included.
Indeed, it is not acceptable that certain companies abuse the force majeure clause to evade their obligation to compensate passengers as stipulated in regulation 261/2004.
Travelers are victims of the current situation and, if no alternative solution is offered to them, they should not additionally bear the financial cost.
Furthermore, travel agencies are exempt from the obligation to reimburse travelers for unused flights.
This, too, is not normal.

Companies, like travel agencies, have insurance policies that cover them in exceptional circumstances, such as the one we are experiencing for the past few days, and it is therefore essential to ensure that travelers are properly compensated for canceled flights.
Mr. President, pandemonium, chaos, paralysis, cacophony, catastrophe, disaster – the words are not lacking in the press to describe the closure of European airspace and its consequences.
I will not dwell on what has already been said, particularly regarding the magnitude of the colossal, one might even say abysmal, financial impact of this crisis, whether direct or indirect.

While I welcome the possibility of considering the granting of exceptional public aid to the aviation sector, already strongly approved since September 11, 2001, I remain nonetheless perplexed by the European management of events.

un. Given that seven hundred and fifty European guides have been harmed, a significant portion of whom remain stranded across the globe, and considering that the economic losses are exponentially increasing with time, how can one explain the need for a

Not one, two, three, or four, but five days for the European Transport Ministers to meet via teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the establishment of differentiated traffic zones.
Two individuals do not dispute the necessity of applying the precautionary principle as an absolute priority, but today, as traffic is gradually reauthorized in areas

assured, with unchanged weather conditions and while the volcano remains active, one is entitled to ask what additional safety guarantees for passengers we could not have provided earlier, more quickly.
Thirdly, an evolving action model has been developed; how will the weather and volcanic activity, which can change by the hour, continue to inform an updated assessment of corridor safety?
Should these test flights be conducted by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this situation persists, worsens, or recurs—which is probable—the management model established will need to incorporate greater coordination among Member States and special operational procedures based on real data, improved

coordination of other modes of transport in exceptional circumstances, but let us also consider the necessary coordination of assistance for the repatriation of the tens of thousands of stranded passengers, who also have a right to information and assistance.
Alternatively, until now, only isolated and national initiatives have been undertaken.
Madam President, I wished, after other speakers, to express my thanks to our colleague Mr. de Vigo, who has accomplished remarkable work under sometimes heated and always engaging conditions.
The debates within the Committee on Constitutional Affairs were lengthy, commensurate with the importance of the matter and the intensity of the interest clearly shown by.
European parliamentarians on the principal subject which concerns them above all and in a perfectly legitimate way: the composition of our Assembly and the modalities for designating its members.

Once again, the rapporteur has managed to gather and synthesize opinions and contributions that were sometimes divergent, producing, I would say, an extremely balanced text reflecting those views and perspectives.
I wanted to thank them for that.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both concerning the convening of the General Assembly and concerning the transitional measures for the composition of our Assembly, are characterized by realism, pragmatism, and effectiveness.
That is, broadly speaking, and on other matters as well, what citizens expect from Europe.
Mr. President, Mr. Dalli, Mr. Commissioner, with considerable conviction, this draft report, as just presented by Mr. Peterle, reiterates the key lines
Director of Communication for the European Commission and is also inspired by the European Parliament resolution of 10 April 2008 on the fight against cancer in our European Union.

Allow me to support the objectives of the European partnership envisioned by the European Commission to combat cancer more effectively, whether it concerns the importance of prevention and early detection, the development of a new cancer prevention model, and above all, the reduction of inequalities within Member States.
I share the concerns and apprehensions expressed within the European Commission's communication and the draft report.
I would like to acknowledge the work done by Mr. Peterli, rapporteur, in the preparation of this report and the compromise proposals put forward to address the various amendments.

As rapporteur for the Socialists and Democrats group, I have wished, among other things, to emphasize the following points: firstly, the increase in annual deaths linked to cancer caused by exposure to carcinogens in the workplace, but also the importance of improved access to

information on medications for cancer patients, as well as the implementation of the REACH regulation and the regular updating of substances of very high concern that include carcinogenic substances, support for initiatives aimed at preventing the importation of goods.

containing carcinogenic chemical substances and strengthening control over the presence of chemicals within the European Union. Finally, developing guidelines for a common definition of disability that may include individuals suffering from chronic illnesses or cancer.
These are the questions we wished to raise, while offering our support for this report project.
Madam President, the oil rig spill in the Bay of Mexico is a veritable ecological and economic catastrophe.
It appears that irregularities may have been observed in the United States Department of the Interior’s issuance of forest permits.
This would constitute an unforgivable carelessness, the consequences of which are incalculable and do not concern only the United States of America.

When one considers that hundreds of offshore drilling permits are granted by states worldwide, if these permits are issued with the same lack of rigor, it would pose a genuine problem for the entire world.
elected officials from European outermost regions and peripheral territories, comprised entirely of islands, almost entirely of islands, nearly one hundred and thirty,
In total, distributed across the three continents, I must express here my very great concern for our islands with regard to the oil exploitation projects at sea.
This is precisely why it is imperative that the European Union, leading by example, rigorously reviews security and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms.
Furthermore, accidental or operational oil spills at sea, not necessarily attributable to Europe, are estimated at tens of thousands of tonnes annually.

Would it not be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives so that offshore platforms are now overseen by an undisputed international scientific authority, which could be established in the form of an international agency?
Following Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancun, the European Union would be honored to initiate genuine global governance for the research, protection, and exploitation of marine resources.
Building on the Barcelona Process, the Union for the Mediterranean represents an opportunity for the development of our relations with the countries of the Eastern and Southern Mediterranean basin.
As Vincent Payon’s excellent report rightly points out, we must neither neglect the potential of this region nor the perils it embodies.

Yet, let us have the lucidity to acknowledge it: since the bombardment of Gaza and with the continuation of the colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean is at an impasse.
The political aspect is stalled.
We are not even certain that the summit planned for next June in Barcelona will indeed take place.
I would not be surprised if we learn, in the coming hours or days, that he is on day release.
We must not abandon hope, but the European Union must assume greater responsibility in the search for a political solution.
We cannot allow the United States to hold a monopoly on the political management of the crisis in this region, which is ours, contenting ourselves with contributing to its development.
The development and stability of the Mediterranean region underpin our security and growth, and for that reason, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best instrument at our disposal.
Mr. President, Commissioner, this concerns a matter of extreme importance regarding consumer protection.
A recent survey indicates that, in the view of Europeans, the situation regarding food security has deteriorated over the past ten years, and one in three consumers remains wary of product quality.
Therefore, updating, simplifying, and clarifying the labeling of foodstuffs within the European Union is an obligation for improved consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
Regarding the color code, we are in favor of this color code provided that it is accompanied by a reference to the nutritional values expressed as a percentage.
I am opposed to mandatory nutrition labeling for wines and spirits.
We desire the elaboration of regulations specific to wines and spirits within the next three years, rather than the five years proposed by the European Commission.
That is what I wished to indicate, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner.
Madam President, High Representative, this attack on civilian vessels by Israeli commandos obviously demands an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credibility could we grant a Commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack occurred in international waters; it therefore concerns the international community, and particularly interests Europe bordering the Mediterranean.
Europe should make its voice heard more and become more deeply involved in seeking a political solution based on two states, each having Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making considerable financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but unfortunately, it is too absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of this Palestinian state.
The financial and budgetary good will that we demonstrate is not enough.
We must also express a political will and take steps to ensure our voices are heard.
The abrupt replacement of the Mavi Marmara by the Israeli army evokes emotion and condemnation.
Emotion at the sight of the nine victims of the civilian assault, condemnation because this interdiction in international waters constitutes a violation of international law.

In doing so, the Israeli government is penalizing its people, because ultimately, we see, with the strengthening of extremist factions, a further distancing from the ultimate goal of security in the region.
Yes, more than ever, the government of Israel must renounce the policy of force.
However, I wish to note that the extensive media coverage surrounding the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation appears indispensable to shed light on the assault, but also on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
And I wish that the government of Israel would accept that this investigation includes substantial international participation in order finally to find the path to justice in this region.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I welcome the new momentum generated by the launch of the Partnership for Modernisation and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, even if it served only that purpose, would at least have the merit of highlighting how essential Russia is as a geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also welcome the positive remarks concerning cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
Some observations, however.

While the requirements of the Union are consistently emphasized, the interests or positions of its partner appear systematically underestimated or dismissed, whether in the realm of energy or in how it can analyze the eastern partnership and the Atlantic aspirations of its closest neighbors.
I also observe that the firmness displayed by most Member States of the Union in their discourse, the virulence of the condemnations of human rights violations, appear reserved solely for Russia.

The statements are more assertive, the diplomacies more muted, as if we were discussing China, for example, regarding these systematic violations of the rule of law, not least concerning the Laogai, this global factory in relation to minimal European social requirements, when our French or European workers are unemployed.

Allow me to recall Father Augusta’s adage, “To the summits by narrow paths,” for it is thus that I view the efforts of today’s Russia, freed from the criminal Marxist poison that, for so many decades, has bled and imprisoned this country.
The current Russian Federation has demonstrated its ability to raise the head of an entire nation, despite the significant difficulties and challenges that still lie ahead.

So, a little modesty, gentlemen Europe experts, especially when the super European state itself fails to achieve any of its lofty goals, despite increasingly costly resources and the progressive domination of states in Western and Central and Eastern Europe.
I cannot also refrain from recalling that this Assembly, with regard to the communist Soviet Union, displayed more leniency than it did toward Russia.

It is, moreover, often the same individuals who yesterday championed the unilateral disarmament of the West and participation in Mr. Gorbachev’s common house who now experience the most virtuous indignations and the greatest reserve regarding the Russia-Union partnership.

On this matter, I must inform you, if you are not already, of new historical facts that will emerge as a result of the gradual translation of Soviet secret archives, archives which a courageous Mr. Pavel Stroilov has managed to acquire and which have already yielded and will continue to yield much

An unwelcome surprise to the dogma of a singular perspective concerning the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was, in truth, Mr. Gorbachev, and to the blunder of today's powerful Europeanists who then, with enthusiasm, sought to make certain Soviet projects possible.
At the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for European states, and our relations must be strengthened to the benefit of all parties.

This country is far closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interests, or shared risks than are certain states you are nevertheless preparing to admit to the European Union.
Prime Minister, it is often said that necessity makes law.
Faced with the crisis, one certainty emerges, a necessity become inevitable: that of innovating, of being creative.

In this capacity, I welcome the step taken by the Council, a step that I hope will ultimately be a giant leap towards genuine economic governance, for let us not be mistaken, the mere coordination of economic policies will remain insufficient.
Can we arrive at a genuine budgetary federation, not forced by circumstances, but because we ourselves would have decided upon it?
Let us return to the Council's decisions that still please me.
Strengthening the preventative pillar of the Stability and Growth Pact is an excellent thing, but there is no genuine fiscal discipline without sanctions for those who fail to comply.
They have been strengthened but not yet specified, which is a regret.

Otherwise, I will express my satisfaction, among other things, with the decisions made, such as the renowned competitiveness assessment dashboard, because it is fundamentally about reconnecting with competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
Let us once again applaud the project to establish a bank tax, the acceptance of a taxation of financial transactions, and the acceleration of the reform of financial regulations.
Mr. President of the Council, these decisions and orientations appeared, only a few months ago, or even a few weeks, unrealistic, illusory, or even truly hypothetical.
You are correct; it's true—it's a profound cultural shift on the scale of European incremental policy.
That being said, it is now mandatory that, in October, the states implement these guidelines very concretely.

It will now depend on the Council whether the step taken is a historic giant leap or merely a pious wish, something we will all bitterly regret, and in particular a majority of citizens will have to endure on a daily basis. Thank you.

Mr. President, we have already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents; many groups are divided on this Gallo report, and evidently, Parliament and all groups still need to discuss because there are contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
That is why we requested that the debate and vote on the Gallo report be postponed until September 2024, when the Conference of Presidents will convene.
Therefore, it is a very straightforward matter.
Given that the fruit is not yet ripe, let us allow it the summer to ripen and discuss the matter in September.
Madam President, I confess I find it difficult to follow my colleagues who so enjoy flexing their muscles and claiming a monopoly on our legitimacy vis-à-vis the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often laughable.
But when the members of this institution, through diligent work and conviction, assert a reasoned position, when
We champion what appears to be a common European interest against rigid states; the situation is changing completely.
In this debate concerning European oversight, the Parliament played that role.
Regarding the European Systemic Risk Board, of which I am the fictitious rapporteur for my group, I have advocated, as has the rapporteur, Madame Goulard, for an ambitious approach.
I have advocated for mechanisms ensuring a degree of efficiency and I have emphasized the preeminence of the European Central Bank.
Why?
because the European Central Bank is indeed the only community institution within this framework and because it has demonstrated its seriousness.
Out of Christian charity, I shall refrain from mentioning the names of all the institutions and all those prominent figures who disappeared abruptly during the storm.
We can declare ourselves happy to have had at least one captain on board during the height of the crisis.
I will therefore be reassured to see tomorrow the macro-prudential oversight supported by a strong Community institution, while micro-prudential oversight will necessarily remain fragmented.
In these troubled times, the European Systemic Risk Board must get to work as quickly as possible.
The future will show whether adjustments will be necessary, but it is essential to begin on sound foundations, as systemic risks affect the entire European and global banking sector.
Mr. President, the final agreement reached on the overhaul of the Industrial Emissions Directive is more than acceptable, and I commend the work of compromise that has been achieved.

This final package restates the key points of the position I defended with several of my colleagues within the environment committee, and which aimed to make this text an ambitious yet realistic piece of legislation.
First, the maintenance of a certain flexibility for companies and the relevant authorities regarding the granting of exemptions.
Next, I wish to acknowledge the new version of the ESN, so controversial and which, now limited to certain sectors, appears much more feasible.

It is also important to emphasize that the agreement reached allows for better coordination with the ETS Directive and definitively removes from the text of the new Directive the irrelevant idea of creating a market for SO₂ and NOx quotas.
However, some caveats should not be overlooked, and particularly those relating to the land.
The Soil Directive remaining pending, this important issue will unfortunately be addressed only by Member States possessing their own legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement reached following the trilogue negotiations.

A substantial effort has been made on all sides to prevent the referral of this text to conciliation, a text which, I must reiterate, is of crucial importance, both for industry and for European environmental policy.
Madam President, each day brings its share of information that shows us the extent of the ecological disaster caused in the Gulf of Mexico by the rupture of the offshore platform.
But let us not forget that other disasters of this kind occur elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular of what is happening today, and has been happening for a long time already, in Nigeria.

That is why, in addition to the moratorium on new drilling, I believe there is a need to promote stricter regulations concerning platform management, not only European regulations but also international ones.
Regarding the European Union, I believe it is necessary for it to proactively equip itself with measures to combat this disaster, and I think it is evident.
as all of this argues, as Madame Damanaky has said, for a firm and resolute choice in favor of clean and renewable energies,
And the European Union should lead by example in this regard.

Mr. President, Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur as the European Union prepares to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports five hundred thousand tonnes of beef.
A new market opening will occur to the detriment of livestock farmers in disadvantaged European areas, without guarantee of adherence to health and social standards.
We cannot accept it.
Europe purchases thirty-eight million tonnes of soybeans and animal feed.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize over nineteen million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies: Cargill, ADM, and Bunge.
Between 2001 and 2004, soybean cultivation destroyed over 1.2 million hectares of tropical and equatorial forests.
It is one of the primary causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the loss of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on regaining autonomy in plant-based proteins for livestock feed.
Environmentally responsible agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be nullified by this draft bilateral agreement.
Once again, the European Commission is selling out its agriculture and farmers to obtain uncertain concessions for service companies.
These concessions will serve no purpose for the peasant families of Mercosur, but the interests of agro-industrial groups.
To be persuaded, it suffices to read the report of the Tyson group, a heavyweight American company in the international meat market.
who announces having invested in Brazil, to quote and this is in his report, using that country as a platform for exporting to Europe.
Other companies, such as Doux, had already anticipated this move by acquiring the Brazilian group Frango Soul in 1998.
Numerous poultry farmers, particularly in Brittany, had been affected by this operation.
Europe appears intent on continuing its policy of relocating operations by intensifying its attacks.
against the peasants. We must stop
Mr. President, many colleagues are concerned about the consequences for European agriculture that the reopening of negotiations for an association agreement with Mercosur could have.
My group and I share these concerns.

It is, indeed, a cause for concern—and as a Member of Parliament representing an outermost region, I have experience with the banana arrangements—that an agreement with Mercosur could inflict serious damage on many European agricultural sectors.
That is why an impact study is absolutely necessary.

It is also to be feared that this agreement will further steer, perhaps excessively, Mercosur's agriculture toward a productivist model, to the detriment of smallholdings that exist in these countries.
Therefore, a balance must be found to ensure that this agreement does not transform the continents of Latin America and Europe into superpowers fundamentally anchored in the dogma of mercantilism.
Mr. President, I would simply like to say that perhaps we have not structured our agenda very well today.

If we allow free trade agreements to introduce products onto European territory that do not respect either our social standards or our environmental standards, the reform of the CAP will be meaningless.
Very clearly, we cannot remain in a situation of hypocrisy where, on the one hand, we impose environmental constraints, sanitary traceability, and safety regulations,
to our farmers, on the grounds that consumers must be protected, and on the other hand, allow products to enter our continent freely without respecting these standards.
The question underlying the negotiation with Mercosur is precisely that one.

And the way in which events were initiated, whatever we are told about the fact that Parliament was very well informed and that matters proceeded with the utmost transparency and clarity, does not lead us to form a positive assessment of a negotiation that takes place while, in parallel, negotiations continue at the WTO.
In the name of coherence, consumer protection, and the protection of our farmers, I do not believe we should continue down this path.

Madam President, I would also like to commend the work done by the rapporteur, José Bové, to recognize the Commissioner, and to acknowledge the intervention of Mr. Dess, who preceded me, regarding the objectives of this report.

I believe it is very important to keep firmly in mind that in the debate we are having, we must address a problem related to price volatility in agriculture and, above all, to the fact that when prices
They increase rapidly at the distribution level, but when prices decrease at the production level, there is no repercussion for consumers.
There is indeed a problem with the organization of the sector, and there is indeed a problem with the distribution of what is known as added value within the sector.

I believe that José Bové’s report offers, in several respects, perspectives that must be highlighted, and on that point I am genuinely addressing the Commission in an effort to escape this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first, of course, is the organization of the sector and the power dynamics within it. And so,
What proposals do we offer to ensure that producers, gathered and organized, have greater influence within the sector to negotiate?
It is the question you raised, Mr. Interprofessional Commissioner, but it is also a question posed on the basis of the contract that will be implemented.
I advocate for, and it is in the report that this contractual basis has a European framework.
One cannot allow each country to resolve this issue.
There must be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
It is a proposition, an inseparable avenue for me.
Secondly, of course, the question of price transparency.
And at that point, I am in favor of establishing this observatory, which is absolutely necessary so that we can inform consumers about price developments.
I support the proposals that are being made and I hope, as Mr. Dess said, that there will be a majority to follow suit.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I wished today to commend this debate, which once again underscores the need for the Union to recognize and value its regional diversity.
In these times of negotiation regarding the new framework programmes for 2014, it seems important to emphasize the accommodations that specific regions should benefit from.
Issues of territorial continuity and cohesion must be at the center of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous, island, or sparsely populated territories requires more than a collection of exceptional measures.
We need a horizontal approach.
We must establish the instruments capable of enabling all areas of community action to coexist synergistically, thereby reinforcing their added value.
Furthermore, as representative of the outermost regions, I eagerly await the Union's new strategy for Overseas Regions, which the Commission services have promised for early 2011.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first, I join my colleague's position regarding the Council’s absence from this Parliament meeting.
I also feel it’s somewhat careless on the part of the Council.
As the next summit approaches on October sixth, China and the European Union must absolutely and resolutely strive to advance together on the issue of climate change.
Last year, at the same time, we were already occupied in this very chamber urging Europe to do everything possible to achieve an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We observed that the result did not meet our expectations and aspirations.
So, the concerns a year later are the same, if anything even more pronounced.

To enable us today to constrain or persuade our partners, we must demonstrate that our resolve is absolutely intact, demonstrating, for example, that we are providing ourselves with the means to honor our commitments to Southern countries.
For this, the implementation of innovative financing and I heard yesterday President Sarkozy’s speech at the UN becomes a necessary certainty.
Therefore, for example, the implementation of a carbon tax at our borders should not be ruled out.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that are not going far enough in their commitment to the climate and much more than a threat ultimately, and a way to protect our jobs and businesses, especially to better address the post-crisis period.

Madam President, I do not support the necessity of revaluing family leave. Raising the minimum threshold for maternity leave is an advancement, a benefit, and one should not be entirely populist when comparing the economic impact to the qualitative benefits that are difficult to quantify.

But the problem is essentially of two kinds: first, the economic context, which is true, but not sufficient to leave millions of families stranded for decades. Second, the legal shortcomings of the report, because the text contains several types of family leave whose legal foundations are not reconcilable.
Let us consider the adoption leave detailed in the text, treating it on an equal footing with maternity and paternity leave.
I personally appreciate, as an adoptive mother and for all those I represent, the desire to grant equivalent rights to biological mothers.
I am, in fact, the small additional package that Madame Morin mentioned to add to the Estrella report.

If the objective is indeed to strengthen the health and rights of women, of all women, in the workplace, adoptive mothers, who have become mothers in the same way as others, are entitled to the same rights and the same workplace protections.
These are mothers like any others, entirely, whether they adopt a child of more or less than twelve months—indeed, no discrimination, please—as it is stipulated in the text.
Regarding adoption, I regret that the text was so little explored.
It was not even informed by the Ramboll impact study.
All of this is not well achieved, which is clearly a weakness.

Nevertheless, despite these reservations, I will support Madame Estrella’s report because, beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better assume their parenthood in a society of

increasingly disillusioned with regard to the education of these young people, but furthermore, because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their work or sacrificing their work for their children.
Finally, we do not sit on the Council, but in Parliament. If we, directly elected representatives, are not ambitious, tell me who will be.
Madam President, Commissioner, President of the Council, I would like to intervene and not revisit the debate as it has unfolded thus far.
We discussed the 2011 budget with the constraints that we know, namely those of a profound crisis affecting Europe, with national public deficits that could lead to two hypotheses.
These national public deficits constrain the European deficit, or these deficits at the national level must give a new direction and a new impetus at the European scale.
That is where the question lies.
I ask you, Monsieur le Commissaire, above all to try to think, when discussing a budgetary revision, when we begin to talk about budgetary prospects for post-2013, to not
to remain wholly immersed in the context of the crisis, except to tell and to tell all the citizens of Europe that, indeed, Europe will remain in crisis for a long time.
Our fundamental problem, indeed, is to manage the crisis and reduce our deficits and debt, but also to prepare for the crisis’s exit.
And that is where the budgetary question arises.

We will not be able to emerge from the crisis, and Joseph Dole stated this immediately, unless the European budget, because it is European, is capable of providing us with the means to regain what we currently lack in terms of growth, job creation, innovation, and research.

That is the crux of the matter, and it is precisely on this point that we must discuss the budget, rather than, as is far too often the case, constantly incorporating the question of the crisis, the question of deficits – and in that respect, the Council is excellent.

I noted that in Deauville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even preemptively announced a treaty reform, without even having discussed anything at all with Mr. von Rompuy to sanction all the states that would not respect budgetary discipline tomorrow.

This is where we stand today at the Council level, while the Parliament is asking for only one thing, and in particular, it is asking the Commission to try to move the European project forward, and that is happening through the budget.
You have noted a number of points on which we are entirely in agreement.
There is a need for greater flexibility.
Obviously, we need to find together a capacity to have a much more flexible budget, because these are necessities; it is the responsiveness of Europe that is at stake.
This also, of course, involves setting priorities and ensuring the effective allocation of the European budget.
We will all agree on this, all agree; it is a necessity.
But where we need to be clear with each other is that we need a timeline; we need to jointly establish goals, Commissioner. This cannot remain merely words, merely commitments, merely

Texts which are, incidentally, very interesting and which I share almost entirely. But now, it will be necessary to get down to specifics, and in particular concerning a key issue around which we are revolving: own resources.

How do we ensure that we have our own resources tomorrow for Europe, not for Europe itself, but for all European citizens, and to rediscover together the path to growth and an even stronger path for Europe tomorrow?
It falls to you, Commissioner.
Mr. President, I would like to focus my remarks on the preparation for the upcoming G20 summits.

Everything has been said by previous speakers regarding European economic governance, on the need to strengthen European economic governance, to reinforce the stability and growth pact, and to better involve the European Parliament and, of course, national parliaments in the process.
I would like to briefly cite two challenges facing our nations and facing members of the G twenty that must be addressed within the framework, in my opinion, of the forthcoming G twenty meetings.
the challenge of currency wars and that of commodity price volatility.
I believe that on these two subjects, which are genuine threats to global growth and cause significant imbalances on our planet, the European Union must

European [policy] is managing to organize itself, to establish common positions, to provide itself with the means to speak with one voice at the forthcoming G20 summits, Seoul but also those that will follow, and more broadly, on the global stage. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate our colleague Diogo Fejo on the quality of the report and on the ambitious proposals it contains.
This also demonstrates that the European Parliament is taking its full place in a debate that is decisive for the future of Europe, and we can only applaud this.
Incidentally, the Greek crisis has been a revealing indicator of the dysfunctions undermining the economic governance of the European Union.
I take note of Mr. Feyot's proposal regarding the establishment of a permanent mechanism for financial stability.
We must also address the problem at its root.
For this, I believe that the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact, and particularly its sanctions.
It is indispensable if we want a sustainable improvement in the budgetary situation of the States, which is not always popular.
It is restrictive, but we have no choice.

I believe the report clearly demonstrates the stakes involved in the marine environment concerning fishing, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological resources, combined with climate change.
It represents a considerable development potential that must be secured, protected, and sustainably enhanced, as the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also notes, rightly so, that the European Union is the world’s leading maritime power and that its outermost regions provide it with the largest exclusive economic zone globally.
In light of such an observation, it therefore falls to the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a grand maritime policy.
If it is not the world’s foremost maritime power doing it, who else will?
However, it must be noted that the resolution does not go very far down this path.
It is not with fifty million euros that one can claim to occupy a position of leadership in global politics.
Finally, while the outermost regions have a recognized strategic position, being present in all oceans, it would have
It was judicious to have them play a major role in a grand ocean strategy, which, unfortunately, the report did not retain, and I regret that. Thank you, Mr. President.
Madame, Monsieur the Commissioner, I would like to revisit the anti-counterfeiting agreement currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement also raises questions in the United States, particularly among officials at the United States Patent and Trademark Office.
Furthermore, seventy-five American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
He rules that ACTA, a mere executive agreement, would be contrary to the U.S. Constitution.
As the European Parliament prepares, as you know, to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, it continues to raise significant concerns and is far from achieving unanimity.
Among our citizens, I believe it would be useful to have from our American interlocutors a very clear response on two points: can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
Is ACTA, in their view, a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement already lacking the participation of China, India, and Brazil, and which would not be implemented by the United States, would greatly lose its credibility.
Thank you.

Mr. President, throughout this difficult birth of the directive on alternative investment funds, I have consistently advocated for the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether or not they are based in the European Union.
This principle sounds like an obvious truth, but this obviousness has encountered countless difficulties.
The result presented to us today is of a satisfactory nature.
I thank the negotiators and especially our rapporteur, Mr. Gauzès, who, after this particularly difficult process for him, deserves a substantial period of leave.
I would particularly like to emphasize that the question of the treatment of third countries must nevertheless be viewed in two ways, whether one is inside or outside the European Union.
Thanks notably to the European Parliament, all funds sold within the European Union will effectively be subject to comparable regulation.
One can therefore speak, to a greater or lesser extent, of fair gaming conditions.

However, during the transitional period, non-European entities will benefit from the national placement regime, while funds and managers of the European Union will be subject to the directive, which is generally more stringent.

The situation differs in markets located outside the European Union. There, European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for funds from third countries.
It would therefore be considerably more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world, as they will be less flexible and more costly.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was partly unavoidable.

Regarding custodians, let us also note that we will make the practice more stringent, particularly due to the new responsibilities they will bear; this increased cost should lead to substantial changes in the profession.

Mr. President, I am not saying this to demonstrate my opposition, but to indicate that this new regulation is far from trivial; its implementation, which is necessary, will also entail difficulties of which we must be aware.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, particularly at the beginning of the 21st century, patients require appropriate information in order to be fully involved in their care pathway, to know where to seek care, to decide on the best treatment in accordance with healthcare professionals, and to strictly adhere to the prescribed treatment.
Today, patients demand independent, comparative information tailored to their individual needs.
Unfortunately, the proposed revisions to the directive transmitted by the European Commission did not adequately address the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical firms, which appears to us as nonsensical in terms of responding to the actual needs of patients.
This operation offers no benefit either to citizens or to Member States.
It signifies, contrary to additional bureaucracy, an increase in expenses and causing patients to take risks.
It is for these reasons that we initially presented a motion to reject these texts, thereby requesting the Commission to reconsider its approach.

This approach, also adopted by my colleague Carl Schlitter from the Green Group, has enabled our rapporteur, Mr. Fechner, whom I salute, to undertake a significant revision of the Commission’s proposals.

Concurrently, we had submitted some sixty amendments aimed at further protecting the health of our citizens and facilitating patients’ access to independent, comparative information tailored to individual needs.

The adoption of these amendments in the environmental committee has enabled greater emphasis to be placed on patients’ rights to information, rather than making the provision of information an option for pharmaceutical industries.

In light of the compromise amendments obtained, we have decided to withdraw our proposal to reject the texts, as the substance of the text has evolved in a favorable direction over the past few months.
The revised draft report has managed to offset the European Commission’s initial proposals.

However, we will continue to refuse that healthcare professionals be exploited to distribute to their patients brochures and information provided by pharmaceutical companies without any oversight from health authorities.
Similarly, we will oppose the authorization of industrial information campaigns, particularly concerning vaccination.
Information cannot freely originate from pharmaceutical firms.

Experience demonstrates that we must be very vigilant, and indeed, I conclude, that what happened with the Mediator drug shows how vigilant we must be and ensure that this point of equilibrium, as we have sought it within this draft report,

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Madam Minister, Union and realism will be explored – at least that is my hope – during tomorrow's vote on our resolution concerning this sixteenth conference of parties on climate change.

I hope that our designated commissioner will be able to champion the pragmatic goals we will need to achieve collectively, but also defend the indispensable conditions stipulated by Europe, which is associated with it.
In these negotiations, we must also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of fairness held by our citizens and our industries.
It is the world that must combat climate change, and not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of an insufficiently protected intellectual property will be essential.
Green technologies must benefit the greatest number, but we must not, for that reason, devalue our current and future knowledge, even for this essential fight against climate change.

Similarly, requesting common methods for calculating emissions, as well as verification and publication of data to ensure that all emitting industries are subject to the same standards, appears to be a perfectly legitimate request and not a bargaining tactic.
Finally, more controversially, and as my colleague mentioned earlier, the shortcomings of the current system of clean development mechanisms will also need to be addressed.
Dear colleagues, we are all too well aware, with regret, that the true power of negotiation is not held by the European Parliament.

But the desire of many Members of the European Parliament, including myself, to work and contribute to a positive outcome of this conference must be encouraged, not neglected, as we have perhaps felt in recent days.
If Europe wishes to be strong within international dialogues, it must be so for all its legislators.
Madam President, the European Union frequently presents economic partnership agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
Does she not despair of seeing these agreements signed as soon as possible?
But the question that concerns us is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that would be so advantageous to them.
Clearly, assessments diverge regarding the quality of these agreements, and as long as these divergences of assessment persist, ACP countries will hesitate to sign them.
Would it not be appropriate to go further in dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of ACP countries?
These individuals wish to discuss development strategy, whereas Europe, often, responds with merely market liberalization.
It is this listening that is required of the ACP-EU Parliamentary Assembly.
I believe that other European bodies should proceed in the same manner if we are to build a genuine strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Christians are undoubtedly among the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, legitimate targets, and the objective is their complete departure from this region—a region that saw the birth of Christianity and in which their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events at Baghdad Cathedral are merely the culmination of a situation we have passively observed for far too long.
The European Union, as a global actor and trading partner of numerous countries in this region, has a responsibility to express strong indignation in light of the situation.
Discriminations, whatever their form, cannot be tolerated.
Democracy will not be victorious in this region until the most fundamental human rights, such as freedom of religion, are respected.
Dear colleagues, we are all concerned by the serious crisis currently unfolding in Côte d'Ivoire.

It is evident that the decision of this country's Constitutional Council to challenge, in violation of the electoral code, the results of elections officially proclaimed by the independent electoral commission is unanimously condemned by the international community.

The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the European Union–ACP Joint Parliamentary Assembly, the COAS, and soon, certainly the European Parliament, demand respect for the official proclamation of the
the results of the elections and the installation of the new President of the Republic as recognized by the independent electoral commission, which, I remind you, is an instance validated by the UN.
All political groups in the European Parliament have expressed, in a joint statement, their agreement on these essential points.

They also called for preventing any escalation of tensions within the country that could lead to civil war, which would be a human, social, and economic disaster for Côte d'Ivoire – a calamity that must, of course, be avoided at all costs.

Madam President, I also wanted to thank our four rapporteurs, who have done remarkable work and have added significant value from the European Parliament to the text initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizens’ initiative that we, at the EPP, are preparing to vote for with enthusiasm is a significant advancement of the Lisbon Treaty.
Let us not be misled; this instrument can genuinely transform the European political landscape, provided it is used with both responsibility and boldness—I repeat, both responsibility and boldness.
It can contribute to the emergence of European citizens directly within the European political debate.

It can contribute to the emergence of a European public opinion, that is to say, men and women who are citizens of Europe, debating together, taking positions together, and uniting on truly European issues.
But let us not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our member states to swiftly adopt the implementing measures where necessary—let us not disappoint our fellow citizens; it concerns the strengthening of European democracy.
I wished, in turn, like several of our colleagues, to address the issue of the persecution of Christians throughout the world, particularly Christians of the East.
No one needs to recall the horrific acts recently committed.
I would like to reiterate, most solemnly, that defending Christians in the East as everywhere in the world, advocating for religious freedom, the diversity of
beliefs, it is to advocate for freedom, democracy, and human rights, which are values at the heart of the European project and which, of course, we are all convinced here are universal values.
It is truly time now, through indignation, emotion, and solemn condemnations, of course, to move from words to actions.
I urgently call on the authorities of the European Union, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, but also all our leaders, the Ministers of Foreign Affairs,
Implement specific measures, establish a precise and concrete action plan, to make respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Madam the High Representative, we are all agreed that the situation in the Sahel region has deteriorated considerably.
and to allow a zone of lawlessness to become established in European ports is a danger that we must combat firmly and without delay.
Extremist groups are proliferating and threatening the lives of civilian populations.
For my part, I deplore the loss of human life and the hostage-taking, and I am concerned for European nationals present there.
Until now, Morocco has been a bulwark against all kinds of trafficking originating from the Sahel.
Alternatively, traffickers of drugs, arms, or human beings are now bypassing Morocco, passing through Mauritania to the Canary Islands and onward to the European Union.
It seems to me that it is the responsibility of the European Union to act to help its Member States bring these threats to an end.
The security of Europe is at stake on our territory, but also in its immediate vicinity.
It is time for us to act, and I ask the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to help restore safety in the Sahel.
That having been said, I would like to join the expressions of sympathy and support that have already been offered to the peoples of Tunisia and Egypt.
It represents a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedom.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to state that the European Union, which has been noted for its lack of response, must indeed stand alongside the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples to help them successfully implement their countries’ openness to reform and establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support Tunisian leaders in undertaking a peaceful transition, preparing for the organization of upcoming elections to secure freedom and enable the Tunisian people to find prosperity through development and social peace, an economy that will allow young people to find employment.

I would conclude by saying that the Union for the Mediterranean faces a significant challenge because the Jasmine Revolution triggered a wave throughout all the states of the Maghreb, the Near East, and the Middle East.
She must implement a robust strategy towards these countries.
But caution, faced with this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of peoples, and stability.
Commissioner, my colleagues have repeatedly pointed this out.

At a time when Europe is reflecting on a common strategy for its supply of raw materials and, in particular, rare earth elements, we cannot overlook the immense potential represented by the intelligent valorization of our waste.

Strengthening European standards to improve the functioning of collection streams, address leakage or illegal diesel export issues, and further increase our collection targets must be at the heart of this legislation.
Let us not forget the principal actor in the success or failure of this regulation: the consumer.
Citizen empowerment is crucial if we wish to implement effective legislation.
And to that end, my dear Karl Heinz, the ecological contribution, among other systems, has proven to be a most relevant tool.

Producers of electrical and electronic equipment must, of course, become more involved in the collection and recycling system, but the citizen cannot be absolved of responsibility regarding the waste they generate.
Our citizens must be actors, not spectators, in European environmental policy.
Madam President, Mr. President, Commissioner, I would also like to share Ms. McGuinness’s observation regarding the essential link between food and agriculture.
The subject that concerns us is the increase in food prices, with the consequences it may have for a number of populations worldwide, but also in Europe.
I would first like to attempt to share an observation.

The trend toward rising agricultural prices and raw agricultural commodities is, in my view, a long-lasting one that will endure for three essential reasons: global demographic evolution and the increase

of the world population. Secondly, we have entered, with climate change, a period of climatic hazards that pose a problem, whether it be drought or flooding. And the third point, because the world is also developing,
With new emerging countries, consumption levels are increasing.
Therefore, the tension on agricultural markets and agricultural commodities is a significant trend.
It is exacerbated by price volatility, and price volatility is a consequence of the financialization of the global economy.
And it is on this subject that we too must address the matter, if we want to resolve the agricultural issue and the food issue.

And to that end, what the commissioner said is important: there are two elements. Yes, transparency regarding inventories is needed, but so too is a public inventory policy in Europe and inventory management on a global scale, particularly at the level of the United Nations.

Secondly, there needs to be regulation of financial markets and financial speculation, particularly by preventing speculative volume from becoming disconnected from the physical quantities exchanged on those markets.

We cannot accept that, regarding food, speculators engage in speculation without considering the consequences it may have, since we are talking about the world's food and the sustenance of humanity. I conclude by saying
This leads me to two major consequences: we need a strong European policy, and we strategically reaffirm Europe's commitment to being a global food and agricultural actor.
Secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that, globally and within Europe, we reinvest in agriculture, as we will need all forms of agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Commissioner, as in 2008, the price of agricultural raw materials is rising on global markets.
We are only three points away from the level of two thousand eight.
The decline in production in certain traditional exporting areas, due to climate change, the diversion of grains for biofuel production, and speculation.
Financial actions have had an upward effect, are responsible for this situation, as shown in the reports of the IMF, French authorities, and as stated by the Commission as well.
The consequences of this new food crisis are severely impacting one point two billion inhabitants worldwide who live below one dollar and fifty cents.
Since October, forty-four million additional people have joined those living below the poverty line.
Just two days before the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take measures similar to those passed in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the U.S. administration has required the limitation and transparency of positions taken by financial institutions in agricultural commodity markets.
This development represents the first step in curbing speculators' appetites.
The impact is dramatic for European livestock farmers as well.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are going bankrupt.
Five years ago, wheat was worth one hundred euros per tonne; today it is trading at nearly three hundred euros.
The situation has therefore changed completely.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals; it would do well today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot wait until 2014 to find solutions.
We must confront the crisis, and I propose three concrete actions.
Firstly, the creation of stockpiles in cereal-producing countries to make them available to livestock farmers at subsidized prices immediately.
Secondly, the indexing of meat prices paid to farmers on the evolution of the cost of livestock feed.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism for transferring a portion of the aid intended for cereal support to animal production. Thank you.
Mr. President, are we in Europe ready to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there's a caveat.
uppercase. The H1N1 influenza episode of two thousand nine demonstrated that each member state reacted independently, with little coherence or even solidarity.

As a hypothetical rapporteur on this file, I believe these observations needed to be made, but more importantly, we needed to go further, to be constructive, concrete for our citizens who, it must be said and this is what seems most regrettable to me, have likely lost some trust in public health messaging.

Ms. Rivasi’s report, to be voted on tomorrow, takes into consideration these fundamental priorities, which include, among others, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between Member States, improved coordination with the
European health institutions, a clarification of the roles of European structures for managing health risks, an evaluation of vaccination strategies and communication implemented in Member States.
It is therefore a good report; I congratulate the rapporteur. It must, of course, not remain a dead letter.
It is the responsibility of our Member States, who retain the essential competencies in this area; it is therefore a genuine responsibility to assume towards our citizens.

Mr. President, I would also like to express my profound emotion following the cowardly assassination on March 2nd last of the Pakistani Minister responsible for Christian minority affairs, Mr. Bhattie.
This assassination, of a terrorist nature, follows numerous other assassinations of courageous, tolerant Pakistanis, lovers of human rights, human rights and women's rights defenders, I must say.

Once again, we urge the Pakistani government to shed full light on this cowardly assassination and to effectively, truly effectively, ensure the protection of those threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
I am, of course, thinking first and foremost, but not exclusively, of Mrs. Sherry Raymond.
I also wished, once again, and with vigor, to urge all competent institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations concerning

to prepare for future cooperation agreements, notably the cooperation agreement between the EU and Pakistan, including a clause on respect for freedom of religion and respect for human rights. Thank you.
Mr. President, for your reference, with the crisis and the bursting of the real estate and credit bubble, the Irish State had to intervene to support the banks.
The Irish public deficit and the cumulative budgetary balance of central, local, and particularly social security administrations were estimated at thirty-two percent of GDP in two thousand ten.

If the Irish government, which can scarcely refinance itself on the markets, wishes to access loans from the mechanism and the European Stability Financial Fund, it will have to meet obligations of a social and fiscal nature, even though these areas fall under the principle of subsidiarity.
In our view, this is not contradictory.
As a physician, I would say that in the case of fever, it is pointless to prescribe antipyretics blindly without seeking to treat the underlying cause.
Should these funds be allocated, it is incumbent upon that State to undertake a fiscal consolidation in order to address its excessive deficit and rectify past errors.
This austerity plan should increase the GDP by ten over the next four years.

Just as an individual bank, without interfering in its personal life and private management, will condition a personal loan on a solvency guarantee, so too can the European Union lend to Ireland based on consolidated solvency.
Without interfering in its private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

It is in this way that, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity, the European Union, based on a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvency passes through the reduction of the statutory minimum wage and an adjustment of pensions without dispensing with fiscal measures.
It is up to Ireland to choose whether or not to implement these measures.

It is not an open door to European Union interference in areas of subsidiarity that would allow, for example, the dangerously imposition of a European minimum wage, but a protection of the stability of the Eurozone through a mutual guarantee process.

It is, of course, appropriate to assist Ireland as with other countries in difficulty, which also protects us, but not at any price, particularly the price of seeing a state unable to repay in the long term, thereby weakening its citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April – as many of us have already mentioned – provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and ineffectiveness of the European sky.
and each of us in this hemicycle has been directly affected.
and five million of our citizens found themselves stranded, with no viable alternative transportation.
A year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still awaited.

A first crisis exercise, as you mentioned, Commissioner, related to volcanic ash, is indeed scheduled for April 13th and 14th, under the coordination of Eurocontrol of ICAO and IATA, but it is essential that EASA assume genuine leadership for the coordination of security measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the VACs in London and Toulouse must be refined using more modern technological means.

These data, as we saw last April, can nevertheless be contradictory and may lead each Member State to make decisions regarding the closure of their airspace less motivated by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of the AESA is essential for proposing a harmonized interpretation of this data, as well as for ensuring the centralization and proper dissemination of information.
Beyond informing pilots, the AESA must establish a data collection mechanism by closely associating Member States, airlines, and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all stakeholders will prevent the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission to be able, together with EASA, to rapidly present concrete proposals that will fully integrate into the realization of the Single European Sky.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, this text is important.
It is not a revolution; we cannot say that everything was bad before and that everything is perfect now.
However, it does nonetheless present a number of major advances at this provisional stage of our work.

The main concerns, in my opinion, relate to improved regulation of distance selling, and particularly online, which is the subject of chapter three, as it is necessary to strengthen consumer rights in this area.
E-commerce is very useful; it expands consumer choice, allows them to obtain the lowest prices, and also enables small and medium-sized enterprises and craftspeople to find new markets.
To progress in this field, it had to be done in a truly European manner, that is to say, on a few highly specific points, to establish complete harmonization of the rights and obligations of each.
Very concretely, an Italian customer purchasing from a Belgian or German website needed to know that, from now on, they would benefit from the same rights and the same protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that its withdrawal period will extend to fourteen days throughout the Union.
This means he will immediately know the total amount he has to pay, without fearing an unpleasant surprise afterward.
That means that, with a double click, it will correctly verify its order.
Obviously, all of this will disrupt certain habits.
In many states, there are subtleties within national law that each is convinced are fundamental, while sometimes they are not even found in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to modify one's habits somewhat in the service of the common and general interest.
Let us be clear: this text will still need to be improved, and we will need to do so in the coming weeks with the Council and the Commission.
I have appreciated the overtures that have just been made in this regard.
But we have already done substantial work thanks to our rapporteur, Andrea Schwab, whom I warmly thank.
But the true fruit of this work is primarily the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all political groups.
Consumer confidence regarding the internal market of the European Union is very fragile.
This political unanimity was necessary to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
At item number seven, after the first paragraph, a first dash to guarantee respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular the
freedom of speech and assembly, and the right to demonstrate peacefully, and to listen to and consider the legitimate demands of protesters and to ensure their safety.
Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, the Open Skies Agreement between Europe and the United States is an advancement, but it is only a step—a step that places Europe before a dilemma.
The Transport Committee and the Committee itself have emphasized this.
Either we accept an agreement that disadvantages European businesses, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the benefits gained since 2008.

Allow me then to draw a parallel with the licenses of private and professional pilots, a text that will be discussed before the summer, as the pilots among whom I count myself find themselves facing a dilemma.
The European Union Aviation Safety Agency, seeking to harmonize licenses across European territory, will do so at the expense of eighty to ninety general aviation pilots.
directly concerned, some holding only a single U.S. license, and to the detriment—and this is important—of the businesses and jobs associated with this activity.
I wish to draw your attention to this project which lacks any security rationale.
There are thirty-one times fewer accidents among license holders.
The objectives of Basic Regulation 216 provide for the recognition and equivalence of licenses, the benefit of which cannot be seen by waiting for hypothetical agreements postponed until 2014.
