Therefore, I propose a very open sky arrangement and even invite you to accompany me when I sometimes visit Parliament, piloting myself, to demonstrate that an American pilot's license is entirely safe.
Madam President, at this stage of our debate, I will inevitably be led to repeat or emphasize certain points that have already been made.

But I also wanted to say that, like many of my colleagues, the problems we are facing, the problems that the entire European Union is currently facing, cannot be resolved by any single Member State alone.
No Member State should find itself alone facing the challenges confronting it and which, in my view, confront the entire European Union once again.
It is therefore truly to the capacity of the European Union to organize itself and to face challenges collectively, in a spirit of solidarity, that I call upon.
I believe the time has truly come now to lay the groundwork for a genuine European policy on immigration and asylum.
More than a year ago, a European asylum and immigration pact had been adopted.
The time has come now, I think, to outline it in a very concrete way.
So, we certainly heard Madame the Commissioner, we heard a number of recommendations she was making.
I wanted to revisit this and strongly emphasize several of these proposals.
Therefore, yes, it is essential to strengthen the resources of the Frontex agency.
I believe it is necessary to bolster Frontex’s human, material, and financial resources, to enable it to more substantially support Operation Hermes and Operation Poseidon.
Yes, additional financial resources are needed for Member States facing, I would say, primarily the accentuated migratory flows we are experiencing today.
and that will be the financial expression of our solidarity.
Yes, it is necessary to forge closer cooperative relationships with the states on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, to support them, of course, to assist them, to find instruments.
Madam Commissioner was mentioning, I believe, that she went to Tunisia to discuss mobility partnerships.
Yes, these instruments must be strengthened in a spirit of responsibility, in a spirit of solidarity, but also in a spirit of precision and concrete action. Thank you.

Mr. Commissioner, you are no doubt aware that the most intense discussions we have had here regarding your communication concern the place of public services, services of general interest, within the single market and their legislative translation.
We have arrived at a compromise formulation that invites you to go beyond your proposal twenty-five, and we ask you to move beyond a mere

communication that would not meet the expectations and needs of the actors, users, and all stakeholders of public services, and that would also fall short of the objectives that, furthermore, you set.
The European Union must deliver a clear and unambiguous message on public services.
To that end, we must create a positive legal framework, either in the form of a regulation or a directive.
The Treaty of Lisbon provides us with its legal foundations.
It is now up to you to translate them into legislative proposals.
I believe the Parliament is ready to follow you in this direction.
Mr. President, first of all, congratulations to all the rapporteurs for their immense work on this discharge, and I also welcome the presence of the Council for this debate.
The European Parliament's seat in Strasbourg is a matter of European identity and is not merely an economic issue.

I am addressing you today in this hemicycle during the debate on the 2009 discharge because the symbol of Franco-German reconciliation is being treated by some members of the budgetary control committee as a mere means of making savings.
The question of parliamentary spending also interests me.
On that matter, I propose holding the group weeks in Strasbourg rather than in Brussels, which would allow us to better utilize our Parliament building in Strasbourg.
Since we wish to make savings, I propose alternatives, for example, the elimination of per diem for our colleagues on Fridays, as well as the elimination of per diem for journalists.
Europe is attractive enough that one is not obliged to give a percentage to journalists.

Let us not hide behind the budgetary argument to seize a significant question that transcends the scope of budgetary control, even though I commend the important work of Villeux, our rapporteur, regarding this discharge.
Finally, since we are discussing economics, I also wish to see the system of compensation for sponsored visitor groups moralized and cleansed.

I do not find it very moral, and it gives a very poor image of our institution, that the group leader should be reimbursed in cash, in actual money, on the day of the visit, without any work, any oversight of what the group has spent.
Occasionally, the allocated sum, I must point out, exceeds the amount of actual expenditures.

It would be logical for groups to send a quotation in advance to the visitor services department, to receive an account from the Parliament regarding expenses, and this to a bank account, and that the balance be paid upon presentation of invoices actually paid, with a ceiling, of course. Thank you.
Madam President, I address the Commission, my colleagues, and I welcome the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today stems from the management of the Schengen Area in 2011.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s; it is, on the contrary, a space that has continued to expand in recent years and now comprises twenty-five states, three of which are not members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, cooperation within Schengen must therefore adapt to the reality it encompasses today, a reality that is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

It is in this sense that the proposals of the Italian and French governments, and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration, should be read.
Mutual trust between the States parties to the Schengen Area is certainly the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust rests on reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates drafts, the entire system becomes faulty.
It must therefore be possible for other States to respond to this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly regulated control of these borders.
In doing so, these failing states will be clearly invited to better control their external borders.

Furthermore, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the spirit of Schengen, to the extent that these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be taken at the European level and not intergovernmentally.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to the entirety of the long-term measures contemplated within the framework of a common migration policy.
It is notably essential to strengthen Frontex, and to provide greater solidarity to support the States located at external borders.
The situation the Mediterranean has experienced in recent years merely highlights a shortcoming of the Schengen acquis.
Within a few weeks, migrants from countries bordering the Mediterranean had accounted for a notable percentage of annual French immigration.
This acquisition is not static, but must instead evolve.
I hope that these proposals will be rapidly adopted, while ensuring improved management of our Schengen area and, in doing so, guaranteeing the security of our common external borders. I thank you.
Mr. President, the European Union has finally imposed sanctions against Syria.
But unfortunately, she seems to be doing so with a trembling hand, carefully avoiding challenging the head of the Syrian regime.
This lack of determination and clarity is obviously interpreted by the demonstrators as a form of abandonment and by the government as an indulgence that allows it to intensify the
repression, a repression so cruel that one cannot even imagine that at the same moment, Syria could be elected to sit on the Human Rights Council of the organization of
of the United Nations, whereas even today, Syrian authorities are denying the UN observers access to the city of Daraa, the scene of terrible violence perpetrated against defenseless civilians.

Syria’s presence on the Human Rights Council would be an insult to the victims and their families, an encouragement for the regime to use brute force against its people, disregarding, precisely, the values that the Human Rights Council must safeguard.
So, Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options are you considering to avert such a disaster?

Madame Mathieu, Mr. President, Madam the Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Carlos Coelho, who has produced a masterpiece of work on this report, and you know how very complicated it was.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen the control of their borders, and they have succeeded.
Whether concerning police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy, or the control of air, maritime, or land borders, the latest assessments are very clear.
All technical criteria are met.
We can only observe this state of affairs.
Bulgaria and Romania are now able to implement the Schengen acquis both technically and in terms of personnel.
Furthermore, should no obstacle today prevent this expansion of the Schengen Area, we note that a number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be strictly followed, particularly with regard to the borders between Bulgaria, Greece, and Turkey, as you know, mutual trust between Schengen states rests on the full respect by those states of their reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates drafts, the entire system becomes faulty.
I sincerely hope that an agreement will be reached at the Council to admit these two countries into the privileged circle formed by the Schengen States.
and we will all measure, within this hemicycle, the scope of this type of decision for the citizens concerned.
Well done again to Mr. Coelho for his report. Thank you, Mr. President.
Mr. President, in its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union set itself the objective of making our economy greener and our transport more modern.
All European institutions have strongly supported this objective, including almost all Member States and our Parliament.
In this context, it is therefore regrettable that, since 2008, several Member States have endeavored to strip the new eurovignette directive proposal of its substance and to block this file.

Today, however, thanks to the tenacity of our rapporteur—and I would like to acknowledge here Saïd el Khadraoui, thanks to his tenacity and that of the shadow rapporteurs in their negotiations with the Council—we finally have a compromise before us.

Certainly, this text is considerably less ambitious than the initial proposal, but it will, for the first time, enable the implementation of the polluter pays principle and internalize external costs of transport such as noise or CO₂ emissions.

To ensure that this eurovignette is not merely a tax but effectively contributes to the improvement of transport in Europe, Member States are also incentivized to reinvest the collected funds in the modernization of transport modes.
Parliament was also successful in securing concrete advancements regarding the interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy goods vehicles.

In order to remain consistent with the political objectives set by our institution, I sincerely hope that we can adopt this compromise proposed to us in the second reading and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, I agree that with liberty and fraternity, there should be equality for farmers and for the countries that have joined us, including those countries returning from the East.
Yes, I concur with you.
I believe we have made a significant stride with this report.
It wasn't easy at the outset, and we were rather in a confrontational dynamic, but we reached a consensus, and that's what matters most.
This consensus safeguards the overall project, and I believe that is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We have succeeded in this endeavor, and it was not easy. I therefore thank the rapporteur Murciudes and all the parliamentarians.
First step.
In this text, we reaffirm the necessity of equality, justice, and equity both among producers and across territories, and I believe that is important.
We have stated very clearly and we have confirmed the maintenance and development of small farms, the consideration of small farms, indispensable for the quality and biodiversity of territories.
I believe that was also fundamental.
The introduction of the concept of making agriculture agronomic, of turning the page on industrial, productivity-focused agriculture, has been enshrined in the texts.
Now, it will be necessary to implement this. It is a condition for making agriculture possible for future generations.
It is not an ideological question.
Finally, today, the concern we have is that, indeed, there are threats to the budget.
It will be necessary to respond to it clearly.

Now, what we are expecting is for us to enter the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate, because beyond the texts, the broad intentions, it is within the legislative debate that we will truly see where we are headed, and that is what we are expecting, naturally, now.
I would still like to conclude by voicing my outrage at Germany’s stance, which has resulted in a reduction of food aid to the poorest in Europe by five.
It was within the budget of the CAP.
I want us to rediscover the way to help the most vulnerable; there are eighty million European citizens who do not eat sufficiently.

Mr. President, while the European Parliament can certainly boast of some notable advances in economic governance, I urge my colleagues to exercise humility, for we are dancing on the brink of the abyss.
Let us be very aware of two things.
The first point is that the European Parliament remained unheard during the Greek crisis.
While, ordinarily, we are so quick to react to all sorts of events with resolutions worldwide, this existential crisis seems to leave us speechless.
I deeply regret that we were unable to send a strong, concrete, simple message to the Greeks, to the governments of the Member States, to European citizens.
The second observation concerns the scope of this package.
By voting for what I desire in these six directives and the regulation, we will certainly enable the euro area to take a step.
a return to a discipline that we have so greatly missed, a step, I say, nothing more, which will demonstrate its utility in the future.
But one need only examine the heated discussions surrounding the overturned qualified majority to measure the distance we still have to travel, when these should be automatic rules and sanctions.
The mechanism of the inverted qualified majority continues to act on some like a scarecrow.
We must nonetheless remain steadfast on the principle.
On a strictly political level, I regret that the benches of the left continue to reject principles of sound budgetary management despite all evidence.
Yes, deficit and sustainable growth are mutually exclusive.
Yes, states must also manage their budgets responsibly, like prudent heads of households, but not through stimulus spending. It is a short-term palliative, but never a sustainable solution.
As the coming weeks prove critical, the task at hand is to refound an economic union.
This morning, we voted on a very important text for the progress of consumer protection in Europe, after three years of work.
It focuses, rightly so, on online purchases, which may, in twenty years, represent twenty-five percent of all commerce in Europe, a quite considerable figure.
These purchases will be transborder in nature.
They will allow consumers to expand their choices and also to pay considerably less.
This represents a genuine advancement.
For SMEs, for all artisans, it is also a very important possibility to broaden their markets.

Among the principal advancements, I would just like to cite two: the cancellation period, which extends to fourteen days, and the recapitalization of all information and the total price to be paid before pressing the final button that confirms the order.

Finally, I am proud, within the context of these explanations of vote, to say that I, but the entire group of our colleagues, voted unanimously across political groups, because, on such a subject, it was not polemic that we needed, but obviously consensus.
If we have obtained it.

Mathieu, two minutes. Welcome, Commissioner. Madam the President, Monsieur and Madame the Commissioner, first and foremost, I wish to commend the efforts of our colleague Carlos Coelho on this very difficult file, which required considerable technical expertise, substantial work, and a thorough understanding of the matter.
The control of our shared territory and our European borders is one of the most important challenges we must face, and technological tools are now more than ever at the service of this challenge.
Indeed, over recent years, we have witnessed an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some qualify as a digital tsunami should certainly be confirmed in the years to come.
The SIS, VIS, and Eurodac are as many essential instruments today for ensuring the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring effective operational management of these databases is therefore a major concern to which it is our responsibility to provide an effective response.

This response is, of course, very delicate, and Carlos Coelho has had to contend with numerous legal, institutional, budgetary, political, and technical obstacles, yet he has nonetheless produced a balanced text that satisfies all stakeholders.
The establishment of this network agency appears, indeed, to be the best solution for ensuring the internal security of the Member States.
No other existing institution or agency could currently assume responsibility for the proper management of these information systems.

It will enable the improvement of existing information systems management, offer greater synergy between these databases, and also allow for the integration of instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate questions that arose in this case was the location of the Agency – where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have bid to host it.

France already hosts the Schengen information system in Strasbourg, where it has ensured its operational management and administration since 1995, and consequently possesses complete technical mastery of it.
Following the conclusions of the European Council of December two thousand three, which prioritized the new Member States, Estonia also wished to receive the seat of this future agency.

It seems to me that the agreement reached is very good. A sort of division of responsibilities—I conclude, Madam President—has occurred by transferring the Agency's headquarters to Tallinn, where governance, strategy, and program design tasks will be carried out.
The development and operation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg.
The cost-effectiveness ratio is quite balanced, and this compromise solution does not undermine centralized IT systems management.
Mr. President, the horizontal social clause and Article Fourteen of the Treaty of Lisbon compellingly guarantee social rights, notably the right to access essential services.
It is time to demonstrate to European citizens that the social Europe is underway.

Therefore, our social achievements must be given the full place they deserve within Community law, by recognizing the specific characteristics of Services of General Interest (SGIs) with regard to competition rules, knowing that these services have a strong local base and are underpinned by actors in the social economy.

Mr. de Rosa’s report provides an opportunity to reaffirm the simple, yet robust and profoundly meaningful principles of equality, universal access to these collectively organized services, which are drivers of well-being and social progress.
Madam Commissioner, you said it was time to move to specifics.
Yes, it is time to move to the concrete. I propose, within this debate, to genuinely create a European legislative instrument for social services.
I therefore invite you to vote for the alternative resolution submitted by the Green group.
Mr. President, debates concerning GMOs must absolutely be based on irrefutable arguments, both scientific and legal alike.
Legally, member states wishing to restrict or prohibit GMOs within their territory required arguments as varied as they were robust.
The rapporteur has broadened the scope of discretion.
Me, for.
As for the scientific basis, it too must be irrefutable.
The Council has repeatedly questioned the scientific assessments of the EFSA, which have consistently been positive regarding GMOs, in contrast to national scientific assessments.

To restore confidence, shouldn't we, Commissioner, first and foremost simply apply the existing legislation which aims to provide considerable scientific guarantees, particularly in terms of long-term impact assessment?
Why have the Council’s recommendations from October two thousand eight remained unfulfilled?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner. First and foremost, I would like to thank our colleague, Simon Bouzitil, for the remarkable work he has done.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal, and we can only congratulate them for it.
This report outlines an agency with tenfold resources, more aligned with the missions assigned to it.
Recent events have demonstrated the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, its Member States, and the support of a robust agency.
Frontex finally obtains the resources to fulfill its missions.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and by benefiting from the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and highly effective.
He is also assigned new responsibilities, such as organizing voluntary returns and processing personal data, so that we can combat cross-border crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This expansion of Frontex’s field of competence enables us to consider and address migration issues through a holistic approach, and not to confine ourselves to a purely mechanical management of borders.
I approve the possibility of exchanging personal data with other European agencies, notably Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has taken its full place in this report.
Strong recognition of human rights is ensured by the proposal to establish a consultative council within the Agency.

I can only commend this comprehensive proposal, which represents a step forward toward sound and responsible management of our external borders in a context where migratory pressures are particularly strong and ongoing. I thank you.

Mr. President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr. Meyer, and my colleagues’ remarks, sometimes critical, but this 2010 activity report is finally a wonderful opportunity to discuss the Committee on Petitions, as it remains too little known.
Yet, it is the Commission, having a direct, sometimes physical, link with the citizen, who can witness our debates firsthand.
She possesses undeniable legitimacy within Parliament as well as extensive expertise owing to her direct relationship with the citizenry.
Indeed, any petitioner may go to Parliament and defend their rights before the petitions committee.
One can also commend the serenity of the discussions, despite the painful cases that are often addressed.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be, attentive to the concerns of its citizens and united in finding and safeguarding solutions.
Unfortunately, avenues for action and means of influence remain limited, particularly regarding the environmental risk of projects sometimes almost completed.
But I see it also when it comes to defending specific cases, such as the rights of the family or the rights of the child in the event of divorce.
We will, incidentally, undertake a mission in November on this subject.
I also regret that the national authorities do not always hasten to provide us with all the necessary information.
I wish to thank the European Commission for the research and verification work it undertakes, even if it could sometimes go further in the pursuit of truth.
I must also acknowledge the constructive work we are undertaking with the European mediator.
I now appeal to citizens: continue to contact us, through petitions, as directly elected representatives.
Our role will always be to safeguard your interests in strict compliance with European law.
Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome this resolution on homelessness because it is our responsibility to underscore its extreme urgency.
We observe first of all that what was a priority yesterday remains so, even more forcefully, today.

The absence of definitions and reliable statistical indicators concerning homelessness should not prevent us from noting, with the crisis as a contributing factor, that the number of people living below the poverty line rose, according to Eurostat, from 79 million in two thousand nine to an estimated 84 million in two thousand eleven.
Dear colleagues, three years ago, our Parliament, concerned with eradicating poverty, requested that Member States bring an end to the issue of cross-border tax schemes by two thousand fifteen.
Today, we ourselves are somewhat closer to our objective.
Has the year 2010, dedicated to the fight against poverty, truly been leveraged by Member States to concretely address this widespread precariousness, the urgency of which has become permanent?
I genuinely question this, and I deeply regret it.

To conclude, I wish to emphasize the necessity of developing a comprehensive, multisectoral strategy to address homelessness because, of course, there is poverty and a lack of housing, certainly, but there are also family problems, health concerns, various addictions, and personal vulnerabilities.
A holistic, effective, and ambitious, yet tailored, approach is required—one that takes into account individuals, the heterogeneous nature of their backgrounds, and their life disruption.
It is a right—at the very least a fundamental one—from which many of the most vulnerable are deprived.
Madam President, these past years, everyone has said it, the European Union has been struck by unprecedented disasters, and the cities here would take the entirety of the debate.
I will still cite the Azedef explosion, the tenth anniversary of which we commemorated less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A strengthened reaction at the European level, as proposed in Ms. Gardini’s report, represents a genuine opportunity to demonstrate solidarity between our populations.

For several years now, the Union has been attempting to make this pooling of our efforts operational, and the time has come to act together and no longer wait for another catastrophe to strike our territories before drawing lessons from it.
Today, it is a matter of making our material, human, and financial resources available to all, in order to prevent further tragedies from occurring.
Madam Commissioner, earlier you stated that risks must be anticipated.

And it is truly regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing from funding the GMES satellite observation program, which is universally recognized as an essential instrument for the prevention and coordination of responses to disasters.
I urge the Commission to reconsider this position and to support these flagship programs that provide Europe with an undeniable added value.
I would like to thank Mrs. Gardini for her excellent report.
I hope that we will adopt it, thereby paving the way for European solidarity in service of the citizen. I thank you.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, the number of people living in poverty and the number of unemployed individuals continues to rise within the European Union.
More than forty-three million Europeans are threatened by food poverty.
The situation is critical.
Today, six member states wish to terminate the food aid program without providing any replacement solution: Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and the Czech Republic.
Indeed, there is a ruling from the Court of Justice, and we must respect it.
However, Commissioner, Parliament questioned you last July, at the initiative of our Green Group, and you made pertinent proposals to safeguard the programme.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions, but given that millions of people depend on this system, we cannot reduce the food assistance budget by a factor of four.
The urgency is real.

If no action is taken by the end of the year, the food bank network will face a shortfall of over three hundred million euros, and there is no guarantee that national governments will be able to step in to fill this gap.
It is therefore a genuine question of solidarity between peoples.
Let us not allow an irresponsible government minority to deprive millions of Europeans of food aid, because it is first and foremost a matter of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the CAP.
We must fundamentally change our methods of production to bring food production closer to populations, particularly the poorest, who have a right to a healthy and balanced diet.
Only a truly sustainable CAP will allow us to ensure that fewer Europeans need food assistance.
The Council must regain its senses and allow those in need to access this vital assistance.
I would like to address, in particular, the future Danish government, which will have the responsibility of ensuring the presidency of the European Union starting in January.
Come to your senses. Does it take riots born of hunger in Europe to realize the pressing need to change our approach?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council has found solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, there is no one left. Parliament made a strong point last time: human beings are more important than finance.
finances, it is high time to reaffirm it.
In any case, we will be very vigilant and will be sure to renew our appeal in a constructive manner.
Six Member States hold the fate of eighteen million Europeans in need within their hands.
six Member States that claim to do nothing more and nothing less than legal formalism.
Legalism is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we fail to express our anger toward those who remain deaf to the cries of alarm raised by associations assisting the most vulnerable?

And we, members of the European Parliament, representatives of all citizens, desire a Europe where national self-interests dictate policies, paying scant regard to the citizens of states facing budgetary difficulties?
There is no question of renationalizing this support.

No, let us maintain this program, give it a stronger legal foundation, but let us not abandon those who, in the immediate term, in 2012, rely on this assistance during particularly difficult times. I thank you.

Mr. President, Commissioner, I will not revisit the cynicism with which the ArcelorMittal group announced the closure of some of its facilities in Europe, and particularly in Belgium, in Liège, ultimately leading to hundreds of direct layoffs and jeopardizing several thousand indirect jobs.
As a resident of Liège, I share the shock and distress of the five hundred eighty-one workers and their families who have been laid off.
But I also think of the severe restructurings announced by the steel group in France, Germany, and Luxembourg.
The reasons cited are always the same: unfavorable prospects for the steel market in Europe, strong competition from imports from China, Korea,
Russia and Brazil, the reduction of the automotive market, and finally the competitiveness gap, for example that of the Liège site, compared to the best factories in Northern Europe.
Alongside this, and despite a difficult 2010, the financial center of the steel group ArcelorMittal Belgique generated a profit of one billion three hundred eighty-four million euros.
He paid zero euros in tax, representing a tax rate of zero.
It is particularly shocking.
Group management is primarily financial, with a stop-and-go policy implemented across multiple sites.
And the closure of sites is, in the view of these leaders, nothing more than an economic adjustment variable where human considerations are of little importance.
That is no longer acceptable. Therefore,
You have spoken, Commissioner, of the rules.
Shouldn’t the Commission now develop a binding code of social responsibility for multinational corporations?

It has been six years now since our Parliament adopted a report concerning relocations, the corporate code of conduct, the reimbursement of subsidies, and mandatory consultation between businesses, trade unions, and public authorities.
Since then, it must be acknowledged that little concrete progress has been made on these various proposals.
So, what does the Commission intend to do in this regard and within what timeframe?
If we are to support the competitiveness of businesses and make Europe an attractive destination for economic investment, we must also adopt a legislative framework.
a strong European response to address relocation and restructuring and to ensure full consideration of another capital: human capital.
Finally, in the case of the Liège site, I hope it will be able to benefit from the intervention of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to retrain the laid-off workers. Thank you.

Madam President, dear colleagues, the wave of layoffs affecting workers across Europe must lead us to reflect on the role we, as political leaders, have to play in the face of multinational companies that act.

without any social ethics, that conduct stock-based layoffs and relocate operations to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, and appease rating agencies, disregarding social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of 20 September last concerning the future of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, Parliament clearly expressed its desire to support, above all, workers affected by the negative effects of restructurings.

But we also asked the Commission to ensure consistency between the interventions of the European Microfinance Facility and the European Union’s industrial policy, notably through the use of structural funds.

We have also insisted that the future regulation of the FEMM include improvements so that the Fund does not produce, as it does today with multinational companies, random, moral effects, as is the case with ArcelorMittal and Nokia.
Mr. Commissioner, we can no longer examine the issues of structural funds and the Adjustment for Globalization Fund separately without
to consider the restructuring strategies of companies that benefit from them without examining the cost-benefit analysis of a policy, I repeat, well...
Mr. President, the European mediator conducts investigations into complaints directed against the institutions and bodies of the European Union with great skill.

This instrument is both necessary to facilitate free movement – the movement of our businesses and our citizens – but it is also a formidable guarantee, particularly in the face of detractors of the Union who too often claim that the European Union is nothing more than an unaccountable bureaucratic machine.
It is clearly nonsense. Europe is doing genuine work on itself, thanks in particular to the European mediator.
But allow me to convey an observation that I deeply regret, one in which the Commission finds itself under heavy criticism.
There are first the figures: sixty-five is the true figure, and not twelve as indicated by the investigations opened by the mediator concerning the European Commission.

There are also stakeholders. Numerous companies come to see us to explain their misunderstanding of a European Commission that remains unresponsive to their requests, particularly regarding access to documents. Similarly, concerning the issue of transparency in decision-making,
Few people enjoy it.
Finally, from personal experience, I must confess that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain Commission services present on the petitions committee.
You are aware that the European Commission is giving us its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and which is necessary.

But it occasionally happens to see representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer a Member of Parliament’s questions or who take refuge in bureaucratic jargon almost as well as politicians, and this, before citizens pleading their case.

I therefore wanted to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative problems identified and resolved by the mediator are Europeans, relieved to be heard but disappointed by its
behaviors of citizens then negatively marked by their confrontation with institutions, potentially creating a feeling of revolt, incomprehension, and, ultimately, perhaps Euroscepticism.
I sincerely hope that these criticisms, and those of the ombudsman against institutions in general, are heard. I thank you.
Madam President, professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and the competitiveness of our European Union – these are indeed the terms in which the subject of today is framed.
We, the PPE group, have offered our support for the report by our colleague, Ms. McClarkin, a report to the development of which we made a significant contribution, and we obviously support it.

key recommendations of this report for greater professional mobility, greater simplification, and efficiency in the procedures for recognition of professional qualifications, while guaranteeing patient safety and consumer safety.
But it is in terms of the path to growth that the challenge of increased professional mobility arises.
Furthermore, the forum for a single market, held in Kraków at the beginning of October, was not mistaken in this regard.

who recalled that Member States should recognize the potential of the single market to stimulate growth and job creation and should act to eliminate all obstacles to the completion of the single market.
Similarly, the European Council of twenty-three October last also set as one of the essential priorities for achieving growth, I quote, intelligent, sustainable,

including the implementation of the twelve priority proposals of the Act for the Single Market, the twelve proposals made by the Commission, among which the recognition of professional qualifications.

We readily see that it is by increasing professional mobility that we can hope to unlock the growth potential inherent in the internal market, our internal market of five hundred million inhabitants and five hundred million consumers.

Professional mobility must therefore allow not only to ensure—if we strengthen it, modernize it, improve it—the free movement of our compatriots within this market, but also, we hope, to acquire additional growth margins.
That is why, and I want to emphasize a practical recommendation, we, the PPE, have particularly provided our support for the implementation of a voluntary professional reform.
Madam President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Kaczmarek, for his excellent work.
I would like to state that it is important for the European Parliament to review annually the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, to the extent that
This Assembly plays a decisive role in strengthening North-South dialogue and in establishing a development policy based on partnership and exchange.
The year two thousand ten proved to be a productive year for the APP, which convened on two occasions, as noted by predecessors in Spain and the DRC, to exchange information, among other things.
on the impact of climate change in ACP countries, the impact of the global crisis, and also on media freedom and independence and food security.
But in 2010, the APP also deployed its first election observation mission for that legislative session.
I had the honor of co-chairing this mission to Burundi for the presidential elections with my colleague Assarid, a Member of Parliament from Mali.
This election observation mission was a resounding success.

We were able to meet all the political actors concerned, and thanks to the dual origin of this TACP delegation – both national and European – we embodied a different legitimacy than European or African missions.
I therefore invite the APP Bureau to renew this experience, which allows for the practical application of solidarity and the privileged relationships that unite the European Union with ACP countries.
I would like to thank Mr. Dardenne for his report.
Indeed, the crisis is economic and financial, but above all, for our citizens, it is a social crisis.
Reducing the number of people in precarious situations by twenty million by the year 2020 requires strong measures involving the various levels of public authority.

Now more than ever, we must uphold the commitments made by the European Union in 2010 during the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion, and during the creation of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion, to establish a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must ensure the sustainability and optimal utilization of European funds, notably the program providing assistance to the most vulnerable, currently maintained, to improve social protection, and to support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly, and dependent individuals.
Poverty is a scourge to be combatted at the systemic level, and the time has come to act to enable the most vulnerable to escape their precarious situation.

We, as policymakers at the European, national, and local levels, must take the necessary steps to ensure their non-discriminatory access to housing, healthcare, justice, education, and a first job, with a minimum income that may be indexed according to the poverty threshold of each Member State.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation, and in the reduction of poverty, will enable us to implement a strategy of sustainable, intelligent, and inclusive growth.
The Europe we desire and need today is a Europe of solidarity.
Mr. President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms. Levine, for her excellent work.

As rapporteur for the opinion of the development committee, I am pleased that the fisheries committee has taken up the elements contained in our opinion, because it is crucial that the development dimension
should be taken into account in measures aimed at combating illegal fishing globally, in the name of policy coherence and close links with development policy.
Indeed, combating illegal fishing requires global solutions and the involvement of all states, including developing nations.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capabilities of States are also taken into account in the actions to be undertaken.
Indeed, one cannot impose the same constraints without supporting measures on developed or developing countries.
Small island states, for example, have very limited capacities.
Therefore, it is necessary to support them in their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
Therefore, the Union must strengthen the financial allocation for the fisheries sector when it concludes agreements in this area with developing countries.

Furthermore, it is crucial that measures to combat illegal fishing are enforced, as this practice undermines the development of countries to the extent that it reduces the financial resources those countries could derive from the economic activity of fishing.
Alternatively, these resources are essential for developing countries to implement social, economic, and educational policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union, when implementing these measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, promote the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside the beneficiary states receiving aid.
Adopting a holistic approach is necessary to curb this scourge, which is illegal fishing. Thank you.
Mr. President, I would like to say that, largely thanks to these outermost regions, the European Union is the world’s leading maritime power.
This is a major asset for Europe as well; the development and implementation of a comprehensive policy concerning the sea, the oceans, and the seabed are essential for the future.
But I fear that with twenty or fifty million euros, it may not be sufficient to realize this grand challenge.

Combating illegal fishing is part of this broader policy, and it is urgent, at the European level, to find an adequate solution to this problem, particularly within the framework of international cooperation.
I also note that the maritime zones of Guadeloupe, French Guiana, Martinique, Mayotte, and Réunion are regularly violated and plundered.
As the report does not mention it, I would like to take this opportunity to draw the attention of my colleagues and the Commission to this particular issue.
Madam President, I would first like to commend the Polish Presidency, which demonstrated dynamism and drive.
Next week, at the Council, our heads of state and government will have to make essential decisions for the future of the euro area and for the future of the Union.
They will also need to seriously address the revival of growth.

That being said, we can clearly see that today, financial stability has become the priority of priorities, and the pressures, the tensions exerted from outside the eurozone, but also within the eurozone, are undermining our credibility, eroding trust.
To hope for the return of confidence, it is necessary to restore financial stability, halt the alarming rise of national deficits and sovereign debt.
Financial stability has become the priority of priorities, it has become a fervent obligation for all.

Our democracies have, moreover, all embarked on very ambitious programs to consolidate their public finances and reduce their debts, but financial stability is also a prerequisite for any resumption of growth.
but one who speaks of financial stability, budgetary discipline – because these go hand in hand, of course – must also speak of solidarity.
It seems important to us to ensure this dual movement of financial stability, budgetary discipline, and solidarity.
A final word on democracy.
Be careful not to undermine the responsibility of our democratic institutions.

Rather than considering recourse to a judicial mechanism to sanction, in the event of budgetary deviations, let us rather consider mechanisms of control and sanction exercised by democratic institutions.

To be completely frank, I am not the spokesperson for the French Minister for Foreign Affairs, and, very frankly, even though I belong to the same political affiliation as him, I am not, I would say, in a constant position to relay the statements of the French Minister for Foreign Affairs.
To be entirely frank once again, I am not aware of any recent statement by Alain Juppé to that effect.
I simply believe that the current position of France is to assert and repeatedly reaffirm that the euro is truly the heart of our European construction, that safeguarding the euro means

That is to say, the safeguarding of this common project and the safeguarding of the European Union. In this movement to safeguard the euro, we must, of course, think about the future, about the protection of younger generations, and about the preservation of peace on our continent.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, tomorrow we will vote for the third time on the new instrument of cooperation at the peace level.
development that outlines support measures in the banana sector for ACP banana-exporting countries following the reduction of their tariff preferences – the BAM.
This aid program has a budget of one hundred and ninety million euros and is directed to ten ACP countries until 2013.
It is of crucial importance to our African and Caribbean partners, as the banana sector holds considerable economic and social weight in these countries.
If the entirety of Parliament's demands regarding the application of delegated acts have not been incorporated into this instrument, I deeply regret that.
We nevertheless managed to achieve progress.
Indeed, the text stipulates clear objectives and precise criteria for the allocation of resources to the Commission.
and the Commission also made a statement specifying the methodology used.

Furthermore, we have a statement from the Council on the forthcoming multiannual financial framework specifying that it will duly account for delegated acts in external assistance instruments after 2013.
Finally, in its resolution, Parliament clarifies—and this point seems crucial to me—that this is in no way a precedent.

I would like to tell you that I am returning from Togo, where the twenty-second session of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly took place, and I believe I can say that our ACP partners are counting on us, given the urgency of the situation.
The funds should have been released two years ago.
We must be aware of the lamentable consequences for our ACP partners if the ICD BAM were to be rejected.
The situation of certain farmers is dramatic; we can no longer wait and must act accordingly.
I therefore rely on you to support the text. Thank you.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, our coordinator Thys Berman is ultimately unable to be present this evening for personal reasons.
However, I know that he fully shares my analysis of this case.

Reaching a consensus on this legislative package has been lengthy and arduous, and while the outcome regarding human rights instruments and ICAI is satisfactory, we are very far from achieving the desired result concerning the standard instrument.

Thus, the agreement reached on this text dismisses with a wave of the hand the mandate given to our negotiating team, which was to place Parliament on an equal footing with the Council on all programming decisions concerning the selection of strategic priorities and financial allocations.
for these are indeed powers of our Assembly and of the very spirit of the Treaty of Lisbon that are at stake here.
The selection of programming priorities is a highly political decision on which our Assembly must have its say.
In categorically refusing to recognize any power of oversight by Parliament and by resorting to shameful tactics, the Council has once again displayed a deplorable ideological retreat.
But Member States must understand that the European Union's external action is now a shared competence between our institutions.
That is why our Parliament must remain sovereign and reject the proposal on the commonplace instrument.
It is the only way we have of demonstrating to the Council and the Commission that Parliament desires greater transparency in Community decisions.
If we lose this battle, the absurd would dictate that we must wait until a new treaty is in place to finally obtain the powers already foreseen by the Treaty of Lisbon.
Mr. President, at the risk of shocking the most federalist among you, I believe that defense policy is inherently a national policy.
They respond to the strategic, diplomatic, and security needs specific to each nation.
Capability sharing is nothing more than a truncation of sovereignty, the single market for military equipment a vast joke, when certain Member States believe that their
The defense sector guarantees itself in Washington, prioritizes equipping itself with American matériel, Europe being incapable, in this domain as in so many others, of imposing community preference.

Regarding the common security challenges faced by Member States of the Union, there is nothing that cannot be resolved through intergovernmental cooperation, independent of any intervention from Brussels.

And I am sorry to say, but entrusting these areas to Ms. Ashton would amount to recognizing that Moody's and Standard & Poor's have the legitimacy to judge our economic policies, to accepting that the Mercosur couple can impose a German Europe on twenty-seven peoples—a pure mental aberration.

For thirty years, and even more so since the disappearance of the Soviet threat, defense budgets have been the first to be sacrificed on the altar of budgetary rigor, to the point of rendering most of our military tools

deficient or dilapidated, and this in the name of purely financial considerations, with each looking to the neighbor or the supposed big brother American for the efforts they are no longer willing to make themselves.
But you are addressing the wrong person.

It is only by returning to independent and resolute national policies that we can individually equip ourselves with the necessary means, not only for our security and national interests, but also for the cooperation of those means in addressing common challenges.
An accumulation of weaknesses and shortcomings never constitutes a strength.

I wished to convey the support of the French delegation of the EPP group for the Treaty on Stability, Coordination and Economic Governance in the European Union and its support for the main conclusions reached by the Council.
Let us not be mistaken.
This treaty represents a significant step towards greater economic and budgetary integration, towards greater financial stability.
Let us say it again here.
There can be no sustainable recovery of growth and employment without sound public finances.
Of course, growth is not decreed; it is not a treaty that, by itself, can revive growth.
But a treaty, being a set of rules and mutual commitments, can foster trust and empowerment.

And as the president of the socialist group saw fit to introduce partisan politics into this chamber, by alluding to the upcoming French presidential election and evoking the socialist candidate in that French presidential election, I wanted to respond.
We, the PPE, consider the declarations of the French socialist candidate, who stated his intention to renegotiate the treaty concluded by twenty-five, to be entirely irresponsible.
Take the file, whatever it may be, and with i.
These words are entirely irresponsible.
They pay little heed to the voice of the French State, nor to the respect for the commitments of the French State.

Madame Ashton, Madagascar, one of the world’s poorest countries, is experiencing a political crisis whose resolution will depend on the implementation of the roadmap leading up to the presidential and legislative elections.
The growth of this country is negative.
Normally, our contribution amounts to approximately fifty percent of this country’s budget.
The European Union has rightly suspended its budgetary support for the GDP of the ninth and tenth FEDs, but not for the MDGs.
Meanwhile, the population suffers, and businesses established in Madagascar are sometimes compelled to contribute against their will.

While supporting your position, we wish you to exert all your influence with the SADC to ensure that the legal and judicial impasse concerning the return of the former president is resolved as soon as possible, as it is one of the most sensitive elements of the implementation of this roadmap.

I would appreciate your opinion on the matter and would also like to inform you that the European Union-Madagascar friendship group that we have just established in the European Parliament is available to work with you and the Commission in the interest of the Malagasy people and in the defense of our Union’s values.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Iturgaiz, on the quality of his work, on the lengthy negotiation process he had to conduct, and on the patience he demonstrated.

We are finally reaching the vote on this report, which is extremely important because it allows us to bring to this hemicycle, to the Commission and the Council, the difficulties and concerns of our fellow citizens.
Here is further proof, if any were needed, of the efficacy of the right to petition in Europe.
Petitions concerning the environment are predominantly focused on waste, which represents a significant concern for our fellow citizens.
This topic must address a societal issue.
We consume at a rapid pace.
We are only now beginning to realize that what is not consumed is thrown away.
This awareness must be absolutely reinforced among citizens; that is clear.
But this report is also a wake-up call for Member States.
It is still worrying to see that the states appear not to be mastering the situation.
Only six Member States have implemented the Waste Framework Directive on time.
The number of complaints received on the matter sometimes demonstrates a lack of transparency in the selection of landfill locations.
Finally, and this is the most troubling, organized crime appears to be doing as it pleases.
A market of seventy-five billion euros inevitably attracts covetousness.
States must send a strong signal.
It is necessary to increase sanctions against companies that disclose public contracts in order to profit from them.
This report serves as a warning to states, but the European Commission must also play its part and ensure the proper implementation of waste directives.
It is necessary to make this file visible, but also credible.
If no one plays along, we will continue to waste time and money on verification and counter-verification procedures that risk lasting for years.
Let us heed the petitioners’ message and halt this waste as quickly as possible.
Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, I would first like to congratulate Mr. Nicholson for the courage he displayed before the Council and the Commission.
Despite this, I fear that what we have achieved will not allow for a balance between producers and industrialists.
This agreement reminds me of the illusion children tell of a paradise where vegetarian lions would graze on grass alongside sheep.
I don't believe it for a second. Since 2003, Mrs. Fischer Bowles has done everything possible to ideologically dismantle dairy quotas.
In October two thousand nine, the Court of Auditors, nonetheless, recognized the effectiveness of these dairy quotas.

Alternatively, today we find ourselves in a situation that will be even more dramatic, and we see what is currently happening in Denmark, where the strongest farms, with increased production, are all facing bankruptcy due to a forty percent drop in land prices.
Is that what we want for the European level?
I say no; a mastery of production with the participation of public authorities is required. I thank you.
Madam Commissioner, the data protection standards of third countries still differ considerably from European standards.
It is, however, our duty to ensure that our minimum European standards of protection, which we uphold, are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is fundamental that personal data be processed fairly and collected for specified and legitimate purposes.
European citizens must be guaranteed the right to access and rectify personal data concerning them, as well as the right to lodge a judicial appeal in the event of a violation of their rights.
It is necessary to act to enable European and international standards to coexist and resolve a potential legal conflict detrimental to European citizens.
European legislation alone is not sufficient.
It must articulate and coexist intelligently with international standards, for we cannot absolve ourselves of our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation echoes debates within this forum.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as establishing a European program for monitoring the financing of terrorism.

Such a system would allow us to have a tool that has proven its effectiveness in the United States, while fully respecting domestic law and therefore the personal data protection of European citizens.
European institutions must continue their commitment in this regard and fully uphold their protection standards. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, thank you to the rapporteurs for their work.

In response to the crisis, the European Union has spent over a year strengthening its economic governance to prevent macroeconomic imbalances and excessive budget deficits threatening the European economy, but this has not prevented social exclusion nor the rise in unemployment.
It is time—no, it is now urgent—that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy become an absolute priority for the European Commission and for the Member States from a growth perspective.

Each state will have to implement a national employment plan, which means that emphasis should be placed on a variety of subjects such as, inter alia, training, reskilling, microcredit, apprenticeships, paid internships, etc.

Alternatively, and as Commissioner Andorre recalled earlier, we have twenty-three million unemployed individuals in Europe, but also twenty-three million SMEs and twenty-three billion euros of European funds dedicated to employment that remain unutilized.
we could almost turn it into a twenty-three, twenty-three strategy.
And this is without accounting for the sixty billion euros of cohesion funds that remain unallocated.
In Denmark and the Netherlands, social initiatives have been implemented and have proven effective, based on flexi-security.
Let us draw inspiration from it.

This also means that our social policy as a whole must be more adapted, with social incentives more advantageous than those linked to unemployment and active support for all socially responsible businesses.
We had poverty reduction targets to achieve by the year 2020, yet we already know they will not be met, due to the lack of robust and adequate measures taken by Member States.

Our role as parliamentarians must therefore be fully exercised, and it is our responsibility to demand that the same energy invested in implementing robust economic governance measures also be directed towards ambitious, effective, and binding social governance measures.
Madam President, undeniably, the cause of women owes much to Europe.
The principle of equality between men and women was already enshrined in the Treaty of Rome and has been repeatedly reaffirmed in numerous subsequent treaties.
Gender equality is truly a fundamental value of our European project.
Consequently, Europe has consistently pursued gender equality and the advancement of women with considerable determination and
Little by little, progress has been made.
Numerous legislative instruments have been adopted, have been implemented, directives.
Here, even within our Parliament, there has been for many years an extremely active and vigilant commission for women's rights and gender equality.
A European institute for gender equality has been established.
Programs are implemented, and financial resources are voted year after year.
More recently, on March 2nd, we had the opportunity to celebrate the second edition of European Equal Treatment Day, equal pay for equal work.
Equal Pay Day. Undeniably, the legislative framework exists, and European commitment has been realized on numerous occasions.
However, it must be acknowledged that the struggle remains relevant—the struggle for gender equality and, in particular, for equal pay.
There is consistently, on average, across all European Union countries, a salary gap of approximately 17%.
17% for equal work, women still earn 17% less than men.
This is, of course, entirely unacceptable.
The Parliament’s Committee on Women’s Rights is currently working on a draft resolution calling on the European Commission to revise the 2006 directive on gender equality.
of treatment, which is one of the most concerning and central battles, at the heart of worries and demands of European women in all our societies.

On another subject, that of the introduction of quotas—quotas both within the decision-making bodies of major corporations and within political life—I come from a country, France, which adopted them long ago, more than
Ten years of binding rules regarding quotas in political life and, more recently, about a year ago, a law for the implementation of quotas on the boards of directors of large companies.
France is not the only country, of course, to have opted for such legislation.
So, what is the assessment after a few years of implementation in one case, a few months in another? It must be acknowledged that things have shifted, that progress has been made.
Therefore, a necessary evil.
Quotas do have an effect.

Madam Commissioner, you have recently taken a significant step towards establishing quotas at the European level within the decision-making bodies of major corporations by launching this large public consultation aimed at gathering opinions on the measures to be implemented, the legislative actions potentially to be implemented.
On this matter, you will have my full and complete support.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, on the occasion of this resolution, allow me to address two topics: first, the challenge of water management globally and in Europe.
Europe, and then a question to the European Commission so that legislative acts can address a number of our concerns related to the common agricultural policy.
The stakes, as we know, are water—the defining issue of the 21st century.
It is because we will have answers that we will have peace in the world and in Europe.
We are aware of the stakes, we are aware of the stakes in terms of management, we are aware of the stakes in terms of food security.

and on the occasion of this forum, which, as our colleague Rivasi recalled, sees far too many purely commercial concerns at the heart of the discussion that has been underway in Marseille in recent days.
A question arises: why is there a lack of coherence between water management, water-related resources, and the Common Agricultural Policy because
Nothing in the reform of the CAP addresses this management, as our colleague Sarbu mentioned earlier.
Therefore, provide us with answers.
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank Mrs. the rapporteur and our assistants for the work done.
This report now lives up to its name, namely, removing obstacles to citizenship.
Europe is a remarkable project, yet it is too frequently observed that it is not yet perfectly defined.
Let us take the economic crisis as an example.
It has brought to light our weaknesses and enabled us to build more robustly the regulatory institutions of our single market.
For the European citizen, it is the same.
The petitions committee, a veritable complaints bureau, records the grievances of our fellow citizens every day.
In three days, the European citizens’ initiative will complete this framework.
Despite all our policies advocating for mobility, adherence to European values, and exchanges, there remain far too many obstacles to the exercise of citizenship.
And a citizen who does not feel European is a citizen who will not go to vote, a citizen who will not see the interest that Europe represents in their everyday life.
With my PPE colleagues, we have put forward a great many proposals, the most numerous, and I wish to thank them for this.
It is a report that must foster a sense of belonging and European identity, which it is our responsibility to recreate and maintain through these measures.
Our Europe must be a Europe that protects.
Commissioner Viviane Reding has put forward twenty-five highly concrete proposals in favor of citizens.
They are essential for restoring trust between the citizen and Europe.
But the proposals contained in this report reflect other expectations of our fellow citizens: online shopping, moving, children’s rights, employment, and the
citizen participation, healthcare abroad, town twinning, minority rights, etc. We still struggle too much to fully leverage the capabilities offered by Europe.
Rights are exercised, claims are heard.
We are its intermediaries here.
The European Year of Citizenship in two thousand thirteen will need to demonstrate to citizens that with free movement, there is also free use of rights in Europe.
I believe that taxation is an interesting tool for influencing behavior.

I believe that energy consumption must be framed with an indicative price signal for the consumer and, above all, I think that to avoid any distortion on the internal market, we must strive to harmonize our tax practices.
The principle of proportional taxation across different levels of energy products therefore appears to me to be a necessity.
In the case at hand, for example, this would allow us to put an end to the diesel tourism we are currently witnessing, which is not an acceptable situation.
I therefore share the philosophy underlying the Commission’s proposed revision of the directive.

Nevertheless, if we are to achieve our objectives in terms of CO₂ emission reduction or energy efficiency, it is also necessary that our collective decisions do not penalize citizens or sectors particularly vulnerable to the

price volatility in global markets, and I’m thinking of the agricultural sector, for example. The proposed directive will have an impact, albeit differentiated according to the taxation level of each Member State, but an impact on the price of diesel nonetheless.
The question is, who will ultimately have to bear this price increase in the final?
Do real, practical, and accessible alternatives for consumers exist?
As a fictitious rapporteur in the environmental committee, I support an ambitious yet, above all, sustainable position for all.

I therefore advocate for greater progressivity and the entry into force of the proposal and its principle of proportionality in twenty thirty, subject to a new impact study updating that on which the Commission is based and which was nevertheless carried out five years ago.

Months earlier, right here, we had a debate concerning the wave of layoffs in Europe resulting from the economic crisis, particularly at Arcelor, a multinational corporation present in nine European member states and which is restructuring its production facilities in Europe in response to stagnant steel demand.

Since the shutdown of two blast furnaces in Belgium, in Luxembourg, and the idling of a blast furnace in France, it is estimated that nearly six direct jobs would be threatened for the year two thousand twelve.

Beyond unacceptable practices such as stop-and-go production, practices that would benefit from better regulation, lies the broader question of European steelmaking and adaptation to change, which demands extremely urgent responses.

Six months ago, the Commission announced the need to conduct, in light of the economic crisis, a new consultation exercise for the responsible management of restructurings with social partners and public authorities.
My question is simple: six months later, where do we stand?

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, I first wish to definitively refute the unfounded allegations concerning the circulation in France of five hundred to one million counterfeit biometric passports purportedly circulating within our country.
France takes the risks of identity document fraud very seriously.
She does not treat offenses in this area lightly.
At the initiative of its government, identity theft is a criminal offense punishable by one year of imprisonment and a fine of fifteen euros.
The conditions for issuing identity documents have been simplified, enabling prefectures to free up additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, in each department, a fraud liaison is designated.
Furthermore, the security measures for the issuance of identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, civil registry data provided may be verified between administrative services as much as possible through electronic means in order to limit the risks of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same strictness applies to proof of residence documents.
The Ministry of the Interior has embarked on a path toward increased security of proof-of-address documents with the insertion of a barcode.

The standard processing of a title request includes authorized consultation of relevant files, comparison of all documents submitted during previous title requests, and potential authentication of supporting documentation.

The securing of title issuance is further guaranteed by the applicant’s double appearance, first at the time of application submission and subsequently for title collection, as well as the taking of two fingerprints.
And without mentioning the enhanced verification procedures for the renewal of lost and stolen titles, for comparative purposes with the data held by the prefectures, I conclude.

Furthermore, France informs international cooperation bodies, and notably Interpol, that I am nearing completion, Mr. President, of the review of passports issued, lost, and stolen, so as to prevent their use for fraudulent purposes.
My dear colleagues, France, just like the rest of the European Union, is committed
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, first of all, an observation: our citizens increasingly wish to find and consume food produced locally and seasonally, notably for reasons of health and quality.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and rapidly to this growing demand.

We must support the development of local infrastructure for producers, such as maintaining local abattoirs, which, while ensuring rigorous sanitary controls, enable the development of short local supply chains and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers market their products and make them known to consumers.
Strengthening these direct relationships will allow farmers to retain a larger share of the added value created on their farms.

It is necessary to promote and facilitate direct sales within the farm and to support collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective sales outlets that allow local consumers access to a wider range of products.

The European Commission must facilitate the emergence, sustainability, and development of direct-to-consumer delivery systems, such as AMAPs in France, which enable nearly three farmers to supply sixty families.

Finally, Member States must be able to add further criteria concerning, in particular, the size of the holding, the volume of production, or the traditional character of the product to define local farming. Thank you.

Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I welcome the fact that this corrective budget concerning ITER funding, which was approved by a large majority in the Budget Committee on March twenty-ninth last,
By funding this additional cost, we avoid discarding a strategic project of fundamental research in which the European Union plays a leading role, and we honor our international commitments.
Let us recall that none of the seven Euratom community partners has questioned their overall contribution to the project.
Japan, despite the Fukushima disaster, has decided to scrupulously honor its budgetary commitments to ITER.
Without this agreement, hundreds of researchers would have had to suspend their work and the ITER project would have experienced detrimental delays.
Today, a thousand people work for ITER in Cadarache.
From 2015 through 2017, the construction of the buildings and the assembly of the machine could require up to four personnel at this site.
To conclude, Mr. President, ITER is a source of pride for Europe and a symbol of our excellence.
Mr. President, Commissioner, and Rapporteur, thank you for the work we have accomplished together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a shared political vision on the major challenges related to the environment, looking towards the year 2020 and beyond.
That is precisely the utility of launching a seventh action program for the environment, by synergizing existing financial frameworks and mobilizing new funding resources.
This programme must guarantee coherence and articulation between the European Union's environmental strategies and sectoral policies, whether in agriculture,
fishing, research and innovation, health, transportation, regional development, land use planning and urban policies, of course.
Despite the economic crisis that is undermining the European Union, we must not succumb to a short-term vision and abandon all ambition in the environmental and climate sphere.
Inaction would be fatal.
The stakes are too high, particularly concerning the efficient use of our resources and the enhancement of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in the sustainable economy and eco-innovation, a source of growth, competitiveness, and employment.
It is our responsibility to promote ecodesign, recycling, but also the environmental labeling of products in order to avoid waste and poor consumption choices.
We cannot overlook this environmental education, essential for European citizens.
The environmental action programme is a policy planning instrument, but it is also a communication tool.

It must provide the necessary readability and predictability for national and local administrations, citizens, but also for businesses and investors regarding the European Union's environmental choices.
European regulation must not become a punishment or a constraint.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, in the face of the profound transformations our world is subject to today, the EU must reform its Generalized Preference System.
As with any compromise, this one does not deviate from the rule.
While satisfying from a strictly commercial perspective, it is far from perfect, as we must keep in mind that this regulation is addressed to developing countries.
In developing its new differentiation paradigm, the Commission states its intention to refocus its action in favor of the poorest countries.
That does not appear entirely sustainable at first glance.
To this end, the Commission nevertheless developed a strictly accounting vision based solely on the criterion of GDP per capita.
One can clearly see the limitation of this approach.
What of the numerous middle-income developing countries with undiversified economies and which are vulnerable to climatic hazards?
The agreement reached with the Council does not address this question, and that is why I urge my colleagues to vote in favor of the three amendments that will be submitted to this text.
Sir Commissioner, the issue of the availability of public consultations in the various languages of the European Union is not new, unfortunately.

It is, in my view, a crucial question, for which I have already not only asked several written questions of the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally questioned Mr. Barroso in writing.

Indeed, the Commission must comply with the principle of equal access to information for all European citizens, as recalled by the Court of First Instance of the European Communities in its judgment of 20 November 2008.
