I was not at all satisfied with the European Commission’s response, which stated that public consultations do not claim to provide a completely representative picture of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission takes into account the fact that certain positions and viewpoints may be overrepresented to the detriment of others.
This is not an answer.
I question the criteria that would allow us to measure an overrepresentation of the European population.
If written consultations are not overrepresented solely due to availability in English, for example, they fail to consult European citizens.
Thus, the result provides a misleading indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.
If we wish to retain written consultations as a tool underpinning the European Commission’s legislative proposals, we must guarantee a democratic, transparent, and equitable process for all citizens.
Thus, if the European Commission chooses written consultations, it must take responsibility and ensure the resources necessary for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
To conclude, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the sole obstacle.

It would also be necessary to integrate into the analysis the excessively short deadlines for submitting contributions, as well as the limited resources deployed by the Commission to communicate about these consultations, which are unfortunately primarily accessible to insiders. Thank you.
The proposed regulation aims to grant the European Commission increased powers to oversee national budgets and economic policies.
The rules will be stricter, and defaulting states will be subjected by Brussels technocrats to budget cuts and structural reforms in order to restore their financial equilibria.
This enhanced monitoring is referred to as guardianship.
States will be penalized, fined, effectively disciplined—sanctions will be strengthened and more automatic.
Even though some amendments aim to prevent austerity measures alone through growth initiatives, your proposals are merely to help people swallow the bitter pill.
Growth, as you know as well as I do, is not decreed.
Without consulting the people and with the complicity of Brussels, we permanently lose our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And when, little by little, according to the technique of the Chinese thief, the European bureaucratic, technocratic, and totalitarian state has finished constituting itself, we will have lost our freedom as a people outright.
Mr. President, without diminishing the importance of the economic choices we must assume, you will permit me to emphasize a remark of a more political nature within the context of this debate.
In recent weeks, we have once again seen evidence of the double-speak of certain European leaders, or those who consider themselves to be such.
As everyone continues to advocate for economic, budgetary, and fiscal policies truly worthy of the name, and this requirement even appears as a condition
a sine qua non of the eurozone’s survival, and yet, once comfortably settled in their positions, it is Mr. Cunning Cross who proceeds to denigrate the balanced recommendations emanating from
the Commission to free itself from certain commitments or, in the worst case, to turn public opinion against these Brussels bureaucrats, as they call themselves.
This irresponsible attitude might be laughable were we not in such a tragic situation.
I tell you plainly, our discussions concerning stability, the necessary consolidation of public finances, or the efforts to be undertaken in terms of growth are indeed destined to
failure if the past’s missteps regarding debt and public deficits do not end and if the Member States’ governments continue their ill-fated course.
We are playing with fire at this moment.
European discipline must apply to all, without exception, even for the Grand Duché of Luxembourg.
It requires a minimum of courage, and our public opinions are ready for it, far more so than some of their leaders would believe.
And a final word to Ms. Goulard, or else I must show her the blue card—I would say, to conclude regarding Ms. Goulard, there is redemption, there is atonement.

Mr. President, I would first like to commend the determination of the European Commission, and particularly your own, Commissioner, for tirelessly placing the recovery and deepening of the internal market at the top of the European agenda.

You recalled, Commissioner, that for over two years now, both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the internal market, to identify the challenges and sectors for which more internal market is needed – more internal market for greater growth, greater competitiveness, and more jobs.

The European Council, for its part, also eventually signaled the considerable importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the internal market, the twelve drivers for growth.
Rather than constantly seeking to invent new instruments of growth, we have every interest in working with the toolbox we already possess.

We therefore seize the opportunity of the resolution that will be submitted to the vote of our Assembly tomorrow to send a strong political message to the Member States regarding greater speed and efficiency in the transposition of Directives already
resulted in greater mobilization and engagement on newly opened construction sites. I will cite only one: the strengthening of worker mobility—greater ease of movement, improved traffic flow.
We shall welcome with great interest, Commissioner, the second stage of the act for the single market that you will present after the summer.
We will demonstrate both political resolve and the ability to put pressure on Member States.
We experienced the mediator scandal some time ago.
We now have the scandal surrounding breast implants, which unfortunately highlights, as you have said, Commissioner, the shortcomings of European health safety.
This breast implant scandal, these fourteen years of fraud from 1996 to 2010, unpunished,
These are five hundred prostheses worn worldwide, these eight implant removals, forty-eight confirmed cases of cancer.
It is now three complaints filed. These figures are alarming, shocking.

How, despite the warnings of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), Mr. Commissioner, and the numerous complaints and convictions regarding fractured prostheses filed in Great Britain and France, in particular, how could the national and European agencies have overlooked such a fraud?
This tragedy has immediately led us to consider improvements to the European system for the control of medical devices, as you explained to us just now.
We must, Commissioner, build a new system today capable of avoiding scandal, but it is a new system that must be built.
It is announced for the autumn, as you indicated, this new legislation.
As a co-drafter of this resolution, I am naturally pleased.
But, Commissioner, you seem to be taking into account a significant portion of our concerns as outlined by this resolution.
So why make an unacceptable exception for so many of the parliamentarians present here?
Why wouldn't one want the creation of a market authorization for the highest-risk class three medical devices?
Mr. Commissioner Dali, could you explain your position to me?
Mr. President, we are currently experiencing a situation with an increase in production of more than two and a half [points/percent]. Simultaneously, industrialists are lowering prices.
In Italy, Germany, England, and throughout Europe, prices are falling.
This clearly indicates that prices are linked to the volume of production, and we need to organize both production volumes and prices simultaneously.
At the same time, today, producers are experiencing an increase of over forty-four percent in the price of plant proteins and thirty percent in the price of cereals.
Parliament has already voted on the need here to ensure that the added value is shared between producers and that farmers are not victims of businesses and large-scale distribution.

I therefore ask the Commission today, but also the Council, to reconsider the questioning of production control, but at the same time, I say very clearly that Member States must clean up their own houses, because there are countries that have respected the rules of quotas and others that have not.
And that, too, is what led to these quotas being questioned.
Therefore, there is a dual responsibility, the Commission and the Member States.
Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, a single European railway space – this is a fine example of European integration policy.
Here is a fine policy wherein European construction is at the heart of the everyday concerns of Europeans.

Too often decried, because of its failings, Europe, at long last, with this directive, shows the way toward a major policy of sustainable transport and opens the field for a major railway investment policy for employment.

I welcome the key measures taken in the organization of the rail network: the establishment of national regulators in each Member State, and the creation of a five-year multiannual investment contract stipulating the financing commitments of the

railway infrastructures, but I also welcomed the implementation of financial flow transparency between managers and operators within the context of integrated companies. The reminder regarding non-discriminatory access to certain

services. Finally, I welcome the confirmation sought by Members of the European Parliament of certain guarantees, particularly on the social front, for example, the absence of a reference to minimum service requirements, as well as complete separation between the network manager and the operator.

But allow me to mention a requirement that we must cease to consider, particularly from the European Commission, the liberalization of the railway sector as the sole strategic horizon for the development of a single railway space, and instead decide upon a European strategy of integrated investment conducive to employment in Europe.
Also, I would like, to conclude, to pose a question to you, Commissioner Callas.
It is three days after the European Council of twenty-eight and twenty-nine June, following the validation of a €120 billion growth pact to revitalize the European economy.
notably through investment in infrastructure. Could you indicate to us, Mr. Commissioner, what sum the European railway sector is likely to benefit from within the framework of this growth pact?

Madam President, we will have a debate on ACTA tomorrow, but I would like to address a question this evening—albeit a peripheral one—that is, nonetheless, extremely important in relation to this matter.
These are the remarks made by Commissioner Gutt in the Committee on International Trade on Wednesday, June 20th.

Let me quote him. If you decide on a negative vote before the European Court rules, allow me to tell you that the Commission will nonetheless continue to pursue the current procedure before the Court of Justice.
we are committed to it.
A negative vote will not halt the proceedings before the Court of Justice.

justice. Not only do I believe these statements misrepresent the treaties, but above all, and this is what I want to denounce, they bear witness to an unacceptable contempt for the European Parliament, for democracy in general, and for the citizens we represent.
Here, at a time when European citizens, as a whole,
Thank you, Mr. President. At this hour, many things have been said.
Sir Commissioner, as for myself, I would like to thank you very warmly.
Thanks to your persistence, your procedural maneuvers, you allow us to demonstrate the importance of the European Parliament as a colegislator.
Thank you, Commissioner, for having spurred hundreds of thousands of citizens to take to the streets and two million eight to sign petitions.
They discovered that democracy is at stake here, that we, the elected European representatives, are the representatives of the people, their representatives.
Thank you once again to the millions of internet users who followed the debates and votes in committee and who continue to follow us today.
I greet them. It is a breath of fresh air in our institutions, too often perceived as technocratic.
Sir Commissioner, but in a democracy, there is also another principle.
It is the fundamental principle, that of responsibility.
Tomorrow, we will take responsibility, and I would like, tomorrow, to also thank you for assuming your responsibility, your failure, the failure of your working method.
I speak on behalf of Maurice Ponga, rapporteur for opinion of the Development Committee on the report by Mr. Gallagher.
It seemed important to me to recall that the European Union, when it wishes to sanction a country practicing unsustainable fishing, must take its level of development into account.

Indeed, in the name of the principle of policy coherence with development objectives, it is crucial, in my view, that measures adopted in fisheries do not undermine the development plans and strategies implemented by the European Union in these countries.
Mr. Gallagher’s draft report reiterates this key idea for our development committee by stipulating that measures must not be unwarranted nor even discriminatory.

I therefore invite the European Commission, when adopting such measures, to respect this principle of policy coherence with development objectives and to ensure that the level of development and the vulnerability of countries are duly taken into account. Thank you.
This third reform of the common fisheries policy must not once again be carried out against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishers are these plunderers of the sea, solely responsible for the poor health of fish stocks, as environmental organizations and the European Commission claim by encompassing all categories of fishing.

It is, of course, essential to preserve fish stocks, but it is also necessary to allow our fishermen to earn a living from their activity and to safeguard the economic fabric, dynamism, and cultural identity of our coastal regions.
Alternatively, the European executive’s main measures will once again move in the direction of reducing the number of fishermen to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than fifty since nineteen eighty-four.

The Commission notably proposes the implementation of transferable individual quotas, a guarantee of industrialization and concentration within the sector, or alternatively, a total ban on discharges that professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project likely suits the industrial fleet, but in its current form would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Mr. President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for the EPP, our colleague Ms. Karins, on this challenging report, given the sensitive nature of bilateral negotiations in the energy sector between European countries and third states.
The agreement reached in trilogue negotiations will allow for the rapid implementation of the Commission's draft decision, and for pragmatic reasons, one can only welcome this.
Europe's energy transition is not progressing quickly enough, certainly, but it is progressing.
A major energy importer, the European Union is structurally dependent on certain supplier countries.

In order to foster a more European perspective on our energy strategy, it had become necessary to disseminate information regarding energy agreements more broadly within the European Commission, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.
Establishing a mechanism for information sharing regarding intergovernmental agreements will therefore enhance transparency in the energy market and thus enable anticipation of energy supply issues.
I am pleased that the present decision does not create any obligation with regard to agreements between commercial companies.
In times of crisis and considering the issues of competition and competitiveness, we had a duty to protect the interests of our businesses and the rules governing the protection of private contracts.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, I would like to thank our two rapporteurs for the work they have done on this file.

It was necessary because we were starting from a very distant point with the Commission's initial proposal, with no specific mention of the outermost regions directly concerned by competition from Latin American countries, nor any automatic triggering mechanism.

of the stabilization mechanism, no possibility offered to our Assembly to request the opening of a safeguard investigation, no consideration of social and environmental standards as potentially constituting unfair competitive advantage.
That is why it is extremely important that tomorrow’s vote validates the progress achieved on these points within the international trade committee.
Despite everything, this is not sufficient because we know that the trigger thresholds for these two regulations are so high that they render these mechanisms practically inapplicable.
Furthermore, the Commission must provide an additional financial allocation to support the competitiveness of Community banana production.
Let us bear in mind that numerous jobs are at stake in these European regions, which already have record unemployment rates.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank Charles Goerens for his excellent report.

We all know here that the European Union provides more than half of the world’s total of official development assistance, and yet, as the MDG deadline of two thousand fifteen approaches, even if some objectives seem
affected, we must ask ourselves how to improve our assistance, to make it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must rest on firm, measurable commitments with a short- and medium-term timeline.
The economic crisis, climate change, the rise of emerging powers, and land grabbing compel us to define new priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

Indeed, a European consensus exists, but we must rethink European and international institutional systems in environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from bodies that function effectively on a decision-making level, such as the WTO, for example.
Finally, and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not solely about charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for ourselves.
It is enough to look at the markets opening up for Europeans in emerging countries: China, Brazil, and India.

Two thousand fifteen will also provide an opportunity to better account for the geostrategic evolution of recent years, as the emerging countries of today were, until recently, still developing countries.
From now on, as indispensable economic powers, these countries must also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at both the European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than a deadline; it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as mere financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both socially and environmentally.

I therefore join here with my colleagues from the other groups and those from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions to request that 2015 be designated European Year for Development and, above all, of responsible development.
Mr. President, the agenda for change proposed by the Commission, in my opinion, raises numerous questions, the primary one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission wishes that, starting in 2014, the selection of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid will be based on the mechanical application of the single criterion of per capita wealth.
Or, as Ms. Ashton reminded us, these questions are not solely of an accounting nature, but warrant a genuine political debate regarding the definition of our priorities in international cooperation.
Furthermore, this differentiated approach, in my opinion, does not align with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries that have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth. These countries should not be unduly penalized for having succeeded in ensuring growth through discipline, good governance, and prudent economic policies.
Madam President, Commissioner, let us acknowledge the initiative taken by Jacques Delors twenty years ago, at the very moment the Berlin Wall was falling.

Despite this, despite all the advances we have observed since the beginning of our debate, it is forced upon us to note that the Single Act is now synonymous with injustice, inequality, and economic liberalism.
I would therefore like to hear from you, Mr. Barnier, Commissioner, to indicate to us how we will together build a more equitable Europe, a facilitating Europe, a protective Europe.

There are a number of avenues to explore, and I would like to hear your thoughts on these avenues that lie at the heart of the economic and social crisis, as we unfortunately know it: tax harmonization, public services,
guardian of the minimum wage in Europe, establishment of strengthened cooperation, job-creating initiatives, facilitate cross-border cooperation and develop a policy of fair exchange.
That is, I believe, the stakes that lie before us twenty years later.
I rely on you, Commissioner, to ensure that we jointly advance this fine policy of European construction.

Mr. President, as a member of the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee, I have closely examined the report by my colleague Regina Bastos concerning the twenty main concerns of citizens and businesses.
and we debated this report, which is also linked to our debate on twenty years of the single market.
Twenty years ago now, the free movement of goods, people, services, and capital was deemed able to fully operate within our living space, exchange space, internal market.

I was particularly interested in the fact that among the questions expressed by our European fellow citizens, the existence of professional qualifications features prominently, and that we truly must be particularly proactive and particularly effective.

That is what our citizens expect in order to truly implement, in the very near future, procedures for the recognition of their titles, their skills, and their professional qualifications that are genuinely faster, simpler, more efficient, and less costly.
It is a genuine challenge.

As a fictitious rapporteur for the PPE group on this subject—the modernization of these procedures—I am actively working with the other members of the IMCO committee to meet this major challenge of mobility.
Greater mobility, for a greater Europe—that is what our citizens are demanding. Thank you.
Mr. President, the Committee on Petitions has this year acquired the right to be automatically associated with the hearings of European citizens’ initiatives.
For me, this is the strong signal of the year 2011 for this Commission.
Citizens already had a commission to turn to in the event of their rights being disregarded, but this will also be the case when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I hope that the Committee on Petitions may increasingly be regarded as the European Parliament’s privileged interlocutor with citizens.
This issue of consideration is also reflected in the results of the petitions committee’s stances.
Too often, we are approached by citizens facing legal complexities on which we would like to take a position. But when the issues are European, then
Although we maintain that solutions should be European, we remain powerless because subsidiarity still does not align with European solutions due to a lack of national will.

I will take the difficult example of transnational divorces. The problems are both national and European when custody or visitation rights extend beyond national borders, those of Germany, for instance.
Despite the glaring difficulties faced by many parents of children born of intercultural unions, we remain powerless to act within Parliament.

My proposal for all European citizens to have the right to a national ombudsman, particularly from Germany, which submits a large number of petitions in the model of the French Defender of Rights, has had no effect.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, this remains a problematic solution reconciling European law and national jurisdiction.
In many cases, European law appears unable to meet the expectations of citizens.
The European Year of Citizenship 2013 will need to address citizens' grievances, listening intently, but we require means of action to be
